$(this).siblings('.ati-toggle-content').toggleClass('hide');\r\n        });\r\n\r\n        // In Chrome, an anchor tag with target=\"_blank\" and a \"mailto:\" href opens a new tab/window as well as the email client\r\n        // I suspect this behavior will be corrected in the future\r\n        // Remove the target=\"_blank\"\r\n        $('ul.wi-affiliationList').find('a[href^=\"mailto:\"]').each(function () {\r\n            $(this).removeAttr('target');\r\n        });\r\n    });\r\n</script>\r\n\r\n \n    </div>\n    <div class=\"oxford-citation-text\">\r\n            <p>Ian D McGreer, Benjamin Cl\u00e9ment, Ramesh Mainali, Daniel P Stark, Max Gronke, Mark Dijkstra, Xiaohui Fan, Fuyan Bian, Brenda Frye, Linhua Jiang, Jean-Paul Kneib, Marceau Limousin, Gregory Walth,  A bright-lensed galaxy at <em>z</em> = 5.4 with strong Ly\u00a0\u03b1 emission, <em>Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society</em>, Volume 479, Issue 1, September 2018, Pages 435\u2013453, <a href=\"https://doi.org/10.1093/mnras/sty1411\">https://doi.org/10.1093/mnras/sty1411</a></p>\r\n        </div>\r\n\r\n    <div class=\"site-menu-item site-menu-lvl-0\">\r\n                        <a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"nav-link mobile-account-institution dummy-link\">\r\n                            Hope Fox Eccles class=\"center-inner-row\">\r\n        <nav class=\"navbar-menu\">\r\n\r\n        </nav>\r\n            <div class=\"navbar-search-container js-navbar-search-container\">\r\n                <a                      <a href=\"javascript:;\" id=\"MicrositeSearchIcon\" class=\"microsite-search-icon navbar-search-submit icon-menu_search\"><span href=\"/mnras/advanced-search\" class=\"advanced-search js-advanced-search\">Advanced Search</a></div>\r\n            </div>            <div class=\"navbar-search-collapsed\"><a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"icon-menu_search js_expand-navsearch\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search Menu</span></a></div>\r\n    </div>\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n<input id=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" name=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"False\" />\r\n\r\n<input id=\"routename\" name=\"RouteName\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"mnras\" /> \n    </div>\n\r\n                    </div>\r\n                </div>\r\n            </div>\r\n            <div id=\"ContentTab\" class=\"content active\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ArticleFulltext widget-instance-OUP_Article_FullText_Widget\">\n        <div class=\"module-widget\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget-items\" data-widgetname=\"ArticleFulltext\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                    <h2 scrollto-destination=118502049 id=\"118502049\" class=\"abstract-title\" >ABSTRACT</h2>\r\n<section class=\"abstract\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">We present a detailed study of an unusually bright, lensed galaxy at <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span> = 5.424 discovered within the CFHTLS imaging survey. With an observed flux of <em>i</em><sub>AB</sub> = 23.0, J141446.82+544631.9 is one of the brightest galaxies known at <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span> &gt; 5. It is characterized by strong Ly\u00a0\u03b1 emission, reaching a peak in (observed) flux density of &gt;10<sup>\u221216</sup>erg\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u2009cm<sup>\u22122</sup>\u00c5<sup>\u22121</sup>. A deep optical spectrum from the Large Binocular Telescope places strong constraints on N\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">v</span> and C\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span> emission, disfavouring an Active Galactic Nucleus (AGN) source for the emission. However, a detection of the N\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span>] \u03bb1486 emission line indicates a hard ionizing continuum, possibly from hot, massive stars. Resolved imaging from <em>HST</em> deblends the galaxy from a foreground interloper; these observations include narrowband imaging of the Ly\u00a0\u03b1 emission, which is marginally resolved on approximately few kpc scales and has EW<sub>0</sub> \u223c 260 \u00c5. The Ly\u00a0\u03b1 emission extends over \u223c2000\u2009 km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup> and is broadly consistent with expanding shell models. Spectral energy distribution fitting that includes <em>Spitzer</em>/IRAC photometry suggests a complex star formation history that includes both a recent burst and an evolved population. J1414+5446 lies 30 arcsec from the centre of a known lensing cluster in the CFHTLS; combined with the foreground contribution, this leads to a highly uncertain estimate for the lensing magnification in the range 5 \u2272 \u03bc \u2272 25. Because of its unusual brightness, J1414+5446 affords unique opportunities for detailed study of an individual galaxy near the epoch of re-ionization and a preview of what can be expected from upcoming wide-area surveys that will yield hundreds of similar objects.</p></section>                        <div class=\"article-metadata-panel clearfix\"></div>\r\n<div class=\"kwd-group\"><a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;(cosmology:) dark ages, re-ionization, first stars&quot;\">(cosmology:) dark ages, re-ionization, first stars</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;galaxies: high-redshift&quot;\">galaxies: high-redshift</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;galaxies: individual: CFHTLS J141446.82+544631.9&quot;\">galaxies: individual: CFHTLS J141446.82+544631.9</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;galaxies: ISM&quot;\">galaxies: ISM</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;galaxies: groups: individual: SL2S J141447+544703&quot;\">galaxies: groups: individual: SL2S J141447+544703</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;gravitational lensing: strong&quot;\">gravitational lensing: strong</a></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=118502051 id=\"118502051\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec1>1 INTRODUCTION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The census of star-forming galaxies near the re-ionization epoch has expanded greatly in recent years, primarily due to deep imaging surveys at optical and near-infrared wavelengths that capture the rest frame ultraviolet emission produced by ongoing star formation (see review by Stark <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib64\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib64\" data-open=\"bib64\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). These surveys generally fall into two classes. Lyman Break Galaxies (LBGs) are colour-selected based on the sharp break in the continuum flux at the Ly\u00a0\u03b1 wavelength induced by the absorption of intervening neutral hydrogen at <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span> \u2273 4. A subset of high-redshift galaxies is characterized by strong Ly\u00a0\u03b1 emission and are classified as Lyman-alpha Emitters (LAEs); they have traditionally been identified by the flux excess present in a narrow bandpass designed to capture the line emission, although powerful IFUs such as MUSE are increasingly being used to conduct line surveys (e.g. Smit et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib62\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib62\" data-open=\"bib62\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). Deep surveys with the <em>Hubble Space Telescope</em> (<em>HST</em>) have been critical in building large samples of faint galaxies at <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span> &gt; 5, now numbering in thousands (Bouwens et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib8\" data-open=\"bib8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>), although extrapolation beyond the observed population is required for galaxies to provide sufficient ionizing photons to completely re-ionize the diffuse intergalactic gas (e.g. Robertson et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib55\" data-open=\"bib55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Broadly speaking, both LBG and LAE surveys at high redshift probe relatively small volumes. The most recent ultra-deep survey field from <em>HST</em> has an area of &lt;5 arcmin<sup>2</sup> (UDF12: Ellis et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Koekemoer et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>); in total, the <em>HST</em> surveys have an area of &lt;0.3\u00a0deg<sup>2</sup> (Bouwens et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib8\" data-open=\"bib8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). Recent ground-based surveys have yielded rarer, brighter LBGs in areas covering a few square degrees. (Willott et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib73\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib73\" data-open=\"bib73\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Bowler et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib9\" data-open=\"bib9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). LAE surveys can be successfully conducted from the ground as the narrow filter can be placed in regions of relatively low sky background between prominent OH sky emission bands (e.g. Kashikawa et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib34\" data-open=\"bib34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>); the Hyper Suprime-Cam (HSC) surveys with the Subaru telescope are now probing LAEs at <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span> = 6\u20137 over areas of tens of square degrees to exquisite depth (Ouchi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). However, by employing a narrow bandpass, these surveys are restricted to thin redshift slices and hence relatively small volumes (\u223c0.5 Gpc<sup>3</sup> for the HSC surveys). Blind spectroscopic surveys with slits or IFUs cover a much wider redshift range but are limited to small areas.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Because of the limited volume, galaxies discovered in the aforementioned surveys tend to be faint and difficult to study in detail. Bright galaxies can be examined with spectroscopic and multiwavelength observations, probing the physical conditions in individual systems (e.g. Bayliss et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Yang et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib78\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib78\" data-open=\"bib78\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Smit et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib62\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib62\" data-open=\"bib62\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) with tools otherwise limited to stacking analyses of large numbers of photometric galaxies (e.g. Jones, Stark &amp; Ellis <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib32\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib32\" data-open=\"bib32\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). The profiles of both the Ly\u00a0\u03b1 emission line (e.g. Gronke, Bull &amp; Dijkstra <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib25\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib25\" data-open=\"bib25\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) and interstellar absorption lines (e.g. Shapley et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib59\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib59\" data-open=\"bib59\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>) probe the covering fraction and kinematics of neutral gas, including large-scale outflows. Metal lines provide constraints on the ionizing radiation field in early galaxies, which may be driven by hard radiation from very hot, metal-poor massive star populations (Mainali et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Stark et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib67\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib67\" data-open=\"bib67\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015a</a>,<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib68\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib68\" data-open=\"bib68\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">b</a>). Finally, mid-infrared photometry with the <em>Spitzer Space Telescope</em> constrains the stellar mass of bright galaxies and the presence of an evolved population of stars, indicating previous bursts of star formation.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We have discovered an extremely bright galaxy at <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span> = 5.426 that was initially selected as a high-redshift quasar candidate. This object was drawn from a relatively wide-area imaging survey: the CFHTLS-W3 field (Gwyn <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib27\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib27\" data-open=\"bib27\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) covers 49\u00a0deg<sup>2</sup> to a depth of <em>i</em> = 25.7. With <em>i</em><sub>AB</sub> = 23.0, it is (to the best of our knowledge) the brightest galaxy known at <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span> &gt; 5, with only a handful of galaxies even comparable in observed flux [e.g. the lensed galaxy A1689_2 at <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span> = 4.87 has<em>I</em><sub>AB</sub> = 23.3 (Frye, Broadhurst &amp; Ben\u00edtez <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>), the LAE J0335 at <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span> \u223c 5.7 has <em>I</em><sub>AB</sub> = 24.3 (Yang et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib78\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib78\" data-open=\"bib78\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a> )]. The galaxy, CFHTLS J141446.82+544631.9 (hereafter J1414+5446), is characterized by a strong Ly\u00a0\u03b1 emission line and a rare detection of N\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span> \u03bb1468 emission. Whether it is <em>intrinsically</em> luminous is not clear, as its magnification due to gravitational lensing is poorly constrained.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The structure of the paper is as follows. First, in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2</a>, we present an array of multiwavelength observations of the galaxy, including optical spectroscopy that confirms its redshift and characterizes the strong Ly\u00a0\u03b1 emission (Section <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2.2</a> and Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2-3\"></span><a href=\"#sec2-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2.3</a>); infrared photometry that probes the rest frame optical emission (Section <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2-5\"></span><a href=\"#sec2-5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2.5</a>); and both new and archival <em>HST</em> imaging that resolves the emission into multiple components (Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2-4\"></span><a href=\"#sec2-4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2.4</a>). Multiband image decomposition is used to characterize the observed morphology as detailed in Section <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3</a>. In Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4</a>, we explore the physical properties of this galaxy: the spatial extent of the UV continuum and Ly\u00a0\u03b1 emission; rest frame UV spectral properties including detailed modelling of the Ly\u00a0\u03b1 line profile; estimates of the gravitational lensing amplification from simulations of the foreground mass; stellar population models from spectral energy distribution (SED) fitting; and finally inferences about the star formation and ionizing spectrum. Brief conclusions are given in Section <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5</a>. All magnitudes are quoted on the AB system (Oke &amp; Gunn <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1983</a>) and when needed a flat \u039bCDM cosmology is adopted with parameters derived from the Planck 2013 results (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$\\Omega _\\Lambda =0.692$|</span> and <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> = 67.8 km s<sup>\u22121</sup> Mpc<sup>\u22121</sup>, Planck Collaboration et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib51\" data-open=\"bib51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014a</a>).</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=118502057 id=\"118502057\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2>2 OBSERVATIONS</h2>\r\n                    <h3 scrollto-destination=118502058 id=\"118502058\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-1>2.1 Initial selection from CFHTLS-W3</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">J1414+5446 was initially selected as a quasar candidate during our survey of faint <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span> \u223c 5 quasars in the CFHTLS imaging fields (McGreer et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). We started with the publicly available images and catalogues from the CFHTLS W3 field (Gwyn <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib27\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib27\" data-open=\"bib27\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>), providing <em>ugriz</em> photometry over the 49-deg<sup>2</sup> field. We adopted the 2 arcsec aperture photometry measurements from the catalogues and then selected high-redshift quasar candidates using the Likelihood method outlined in Kirkpatrick et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) that assigns quasar probabilities based on the observed fluxes. Further details of our selection method can be found in McGreer et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">J1414+5446 could also have been selected by simple colour criteria; e.g. the colour cuts we adopted in McGreer et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>) to select <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span> = 5 quasars. Although J1414+5446 proved to be a galaxy, we did not reject it as such using morphological criteria from the CFHT imaging. At this flux level star/galaxy separation is challenging; at the time J1414+5446 was targeted, we mainly eliminated galaxies by visual inspection of the images. Inspection of the CFHT images of J1414+5446 did not indicate that it was resolved; see Fig. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"118502061\" scrollto-destination=\"118502061\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/1/10.1093_mnras_sty1411/1/m_sty1411fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611465923&amp;Signature=4YGcogejWCGLy6IMqUPoCVSYpKLOosvFIFY1hfEFMcoFS~iS~RLkSpJpZ5P7qiJvL3bC1osRZdD~Z7RCAgPkZG-q5VO3fntbFCTcHlIv2spN91BBNVEGpys~XxHR31vYhbOJjE85khYVrW6vd3bezbll75E~MOmYaO3Uxb76QLz1o8wPNmXBOxeDpKL5f00ebLrAlanuX2YdUBmjQfe4s-NKOtQGtDU27Ed4af2yC9-k~ispAgzVyiYcDKCTdWld0N4IVAktvJjuWk3goyEAXio2qRy2FC~DDR2InrsDffyOL2AAbMSHiO9wc4p-HfVbI8oMU-TaCAMFyxMXIEpo7A__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Colour image of the \u223c2 arcmin field surrounding J1414+5446. The colour image is generated from the CFHT gri images using the Lupton et\u00a0al. (2004) method. The brightest galaxy in the foreground group SL2S J141447+544703 (Cabanac et\u00a0al. 2007) is clearly visible just above the image centre, as well as the large number of group member galaxies with similar colours. J1414+5446 lies just below the image centre, highlighted by the box. The panels in the bottom row display cutout images with a size of 15 arcsec from the CFHT griz, LBT/LUCI Ks, and Spitzer/IRAC 3.6-\u03bcm and 4.5-\u03bcm data (left to right). A 3 arcsec scalebar is provided in the leftmost panel (g-band) as a thick red line. J1414+5446 is not clearly resolved in any image, including the high-S/N i-band image that contains the Ly\u00a0\u03b1 emission.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1411fig1.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/118502061/sty1411fig1.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1411fig1.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"118502061\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/1/10.1093_mnras_sty1411/1/sty1411fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611465923&Signature=xFEHSUSuTC08B6Hw-Lvq1vedRtDSIpn5sR9YjT0YhFsgUHd2RNc0h80PNw4eHP69cSzKAkhdptkOacDlJMexq00SVvgYX3Y8uYCBrCYlLqmSjP5ZFXArE2amWBGR2zGXOs9ObVMV7aTlfyQ4KTxXAF4gcJCFy~Lq4JVtPhqOtsqNMflNlsVDKQgm6yTcquXSOYaz3VCp4tueVwo07cFofdrDRxBdkBHsxeMqeLITcVvoP~BjYgciIXDM7xGV2k55R8sTVp8zXWUvZhqF0KLOy-wmm5lqphwIcEyibCZTVt5h~sbYPd6UIqKQ6G1-ZEtpxcf59jGoMQucK2eftNr2Kg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=118502061&ar=5026178&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1411fig1.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Colour image of the \u223c2 arcmin field surrounding J1414+5446. The colour image is generated from the CFHT <em>gri</em> images using the Lupton et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib41\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib41\" data-open=\"bib41\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>) method. The brightest galaxy in the foreground group SL2S J141447+544703 (Cabanac et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib11\" data-open=\"bib11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>) is clearly visible just above the image centre, as well as the large number of group member galaxies with similar colours. J1414+5446 lies just below the image centre, highlighted by the box. The panels in the bottom row display cutout images with a size of 15 arcsec from the CFHT <em>griz</em>, LBT/LUCI <em>K</em><sub>s</sub>, and Spitzer/IRAC 3.6-\u03bcm and 4.5-\u03bcm data (left to right). A 3 arcsec scalebar is provided in the leftmost panel (<em>g</em>-band) as a thick red line. J1414+5446 is not clearly resolved in any image, including the high-<em>S</em>/<em>N i</em>-band image that contains the Ly\u00a0\u03b1 emission.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/1/10.1093_mnras_sty1411/1/m_sty1411fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611465923&amp;Signature=4YGcogejWCGLy6IMqUPoCVSYpKLOosvFIFY1hfEFMcoFS~iS~RLkSpJpZ5P7qiJvL3bC1osRZdD~Z7RCAgPkZG-q5VO3fntbFCTcHlIv2spN91BBNVEGpys~XxHR31vYhbOJjE85khYVrW6vd3bezbll75E~MOmYaO3Uxb76QLz1o8wPNmXBOxeDpKL5f00ebLrAlanuX2YdUBmjQfe4s-NKOtQGtDU27Ed4af2yC9-k~ispAgzVyiYcDKCTdWld0N4IVAktvJjuWk3goyEAXio2qRy2FC~DDR2InrsDffyOL2AAbMSHiO9wc4p-HfVbI8oMU-TaCAMFyxMXIEpo7A__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Colour image of the \u223c2 arcmin field surrounding J1414+5446. The brightest galaxy in the foreground group SL2S J141447+544703 (Cabanac et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib11\" data-open=\"bib11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>) is clearly visible just above the image centre, as well as the large number of group member galaxies with similar colours. A 3 arcsec scalebar is provided in the leftmost panel (<em>g</em>-band) as a thick red line. J1414+5446 is not clearly resolved in any image, including the high-<em>S</em>/<em>N i</em>-band image that contains the Ly\u00a0\u03b1 emission.</p></div></div>                        <a id=\"118502062\" scrollto-destination=\"118502062\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig2\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/1/10.1093_mnras_sty1411/1/m_sty1411fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611465923&amp;Signature=bkeaBqnX4jY~g7vHALXfxWhdixVKTkFgnI6VbYS9fDaNptDXqgdKSm-6bHAbKdaM3G8xb5MRscWLhSkAtWPmP5ZoA66lhyK~UPzBVXXgseXVA9cJW0jYi8lRO-zOd19O80OslRe~pZo05hE8sCvLX0kWzq4dz7dF7K7CfQ3JHWROGxE3o8sBszUQTZZzsP6UNcHKtqJKNOxVhd-TV1uRA7IpIwdmfbHFPw1QiBCwq2DGgopeIcquO4MaGOHnVB~UcJnsZe8qJPyV7U~hALyajXGur5JRBQwt396GZdk2uMEUkh5EhABBI8H1Np60~XTcwIk5yX4c9f~3I7ma11wM-g__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"LBT/MODS1 g- and i-band image cutouts of J1414+5446, with the same orientation as in Fig.1. The g-band image has been re-binned by a factor of 2 and is displayed on an arcsinh scale to enhance the weak detection of J1414+5446. Although faint, this clearly confirms the \u223c2\u03c3 flux measured from the CFHT image. The i-band image is displayed at native resolution; J1414+5446 is detected at high S/N and is unresolved in 0${^{\\prime\\prime}_{.}}$6 seeing.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1411fig2.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/118502062/sty1411fig2.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1411fig2.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"118502062\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/1/10.1093_mnras_sty1411/1/sty1411fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611465923&Signature=fyWLSdIZ0EOu5u2gaGzHU7tA3r3KdOAF8wa3TMcSKZ2zuhzgUSLcka7LMXccJ39h18TYQaA25KLDPV8e1aHBHWwOFTlKCbplAKNm6QaX8e5okOdgbr2BZMQTTwmWyMdDC~iAEAaN2hTjWbzQHzJOjX88HTdeJbmssJKwLwvTTemHx4CnoxvYw4-BXasP66aNgJv29Pet2hKpi2siWyZv4MgvAc-M16EZQSK1iOfd36aFqC~AIn9d3f~HdGaMEFeGEunv~aicaNIsXkkMA~iIcZJCgSjo044qo2wc2CTTtNcQbPfhywJyzCeZP~0esPy7-ikScu-TxoAVJj9~fpbmiw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=118502062&ar=5026178&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1411fig2.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">LBT/MODS1 <em>g-</em> and <em>i</em>-band image cutouts of J1414+5446, with the same orientation as in Fig.<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>. The <em>g</em>-band image has been re-binned by a factor of 2 and is displayed on an arcsinh scale to enhance the weak detection of J1414+5446. Although faint, this clearly confirms the \u223c2\u03c3 flux measured from the CFHT image. The <em>i</em>-band image is displayed at native resolution; J1414+5446 is detected at high <em>S</em>/<em>N</em> and is unresolved in 0<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${^{\\prime\\prime}_{.}}$|</span>6 seeing.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig2\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/1/10.1093_mnras_sty1411/1/m_sty1411fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611465923&amp;Signature=bkeaBqnX4jY~g7vHALXfxWhdixVKTkFgnI6VbYS9fDaNptDXqgdKSm-6bHAbKdaM3G8xb5MRscWLhSkAtWPmP5ZoA66lhyK~UPzBVXXgseXVA9cJW0jYi8lRO-zOd19O80OslRe~pZo05hE8sCvLX0kWzq4dz7dF7K7CfQ3JHWROGxE3o8sBszUQTZZzsP6UNcHKtqJKNOxVhd-TV1uRA7IpIwdmfbHFPw1QiBCwq2DGgopeIcquO4MaGOHnVB~UcJnsZe8qJPyV7U~hALyajXGur5JRBQwt396GZdk2uMEUkh5EhABBI8H1Np60~XTcwIk5yX4c9f~3I7ma11wM-g__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"LBT/MODS1 g- and i-band image cutouts of J1414+5446, with the same orientation as in Fig.1. The g-band image has been re-binned by a factor of 2 and is displayed on an arcsinh scale to enhance the weak detection of J1414+5446. Although faint, this clearly confirms the \u223c2\u03c3 flux measured from the CFHT image. The i-band image is displayed at native resolution; J1414+5446 is detected at high S/N and is unresolved in 0${^{\\prime\\prime}_{.}}$6 seeing.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1411fig2.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/118502062/sty1411fig2.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1411fig2.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"118502062\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/1/10.1093_mnras_sty1411/1/sty1411fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611465923&Signature=fyWLSdIZ0EOu5u2gaGzHU7tA3r3KdOAF8wa3TMcSKZ2zuhzgUSLcka7LMXccJ39h18TYQaA25KLDPV8e1aHBHWwOFTlKCbplAKNm6QaX8e5okOdgbr2BZMQTTwmWyMdDC~iAEAaN2hTjWbzQHzJOjX88HTdeJbmssJKwLwvTTemHx4CnoxvYw4-BXasP66aNgJv29Pet2hKpi2siWyZv4MgvAc-M16EZQSK1iOfd36aFqC~AIn9d3f~HdGaMEFeGEunv~aicaNIsXkkMA~iIcZJCgSjo044qo2wc2CTTtNcQbPfhywJyzCeZP~0esPy7-ikScu-TxoAVJj9~fpbmiw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=118502062&ar=5026178&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1411fig2.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">LBT/MODS1 <em>g-</em> and <em>i</em>-band image cutouts of J1414+5446, with the same orientation as in Fig.<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>. The <em>g</em>-band image has been re-binned by a factor of 2 and is displayed on an arcsinh scale to enhance the weak detection of J1414+5446. Although faint, this clearly confirms the \u223c2\u03c3 flux measured from the CFHT image. The <em>i</em>-band image is displayed at native resolution; J1414+5446 is detected at high <em>S</em>/<em>N</em> and is unresolved in 0<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${^{\\prime\\prime}_{.}}$|</span>6 seeing.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">J1414+5446 is covered by two independent pointings in the CFHTLS-W3 field (W3+0+0 and W3-0+0). During selection, we used the aperture photometry from a single field. We have since updated the photometry, first by using Point Spread Function (PSF)-shaped fluxes from PSFEx and second by co-adding the two sets of measurements. The improved CFHT photometry is provided in Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>. The weak detections in the <em>u</em> and <em>g</em> bands are unexpected for a galaxy at this redshift. At the time of target selection, the significance of these detections was inconclusive and thus the object was not rejected as a high-redshift candidate. This issue will be discussed further in Section <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.1</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"118502064\" scrollto-destination=\"118502064\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl1\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl1\" data-id=\"tbl1\"><span class=\"label\">Table 1.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Photometry of J1414+5446 based on total fluxes measured through elliptical apertures (<span class=\"monospace\">SExtractor</span> MAG_AUTO).</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Source<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>CFHT\u00a0</td><td><em>u</em>\u00a0</td><td>26.45 \u00b1 0.28\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td><em>g</em>\u00a0</td><td>26.58 \u00b1 0.23\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td><em>r</em>\u00a0</td><td>25.03 \u00b1 0.08\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td><em>i</em>\u00a0</td><td>23.00 \u00b1 0.02\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span>\u00a0</td><td>23.45 \u00b1 0.09\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>LBT/MODS\u00a0</td><td><em>g</em>\u00a0</td><td>26.61 \u00b1 0.30\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td><em>i</em>\u00a0</td><td>22.89 \u00b1 0.02\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>LBT/LUCI\u00a0</td><td><em>J</em>\u00a0</td><td>23.77 \u00b1 0.37\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td><em>K</em><sub>s</sub>\u00a0</td><td>23.14 \u00b1 0.25\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Spitzer\u00a0</td><td>3.6 \u03bcm\u00a0</td><td>22.37 \u00b1 0.09\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>4.5 \u03bcm\u00a0</td><td>22.03 \u00b1 0.06\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th>Source<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Band<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>AB mag<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>CFHT\u00a0</td><td><em>u</em>\u00a0</td><td>26.45 \u00b1 0.28\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td><em>g</em>\u00a0</td><td>26.58 \u00b1 0.23\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td><em>r</em>\u00a0</td><td>25.03 \u00b1 0.08\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td><em>i</em>\u00a0</td><td>23.00 \u00b1 0.02\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span>\u00a0</td><td>23.45 \u00b1 0.09\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>LBT/MODS\u00a0</td><td><em>g</em>\u00a0</td><td>26.61 \u00b1 0.30\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td><em>i</em>\u00a0</td><td>22.89 \u00b1 0.02\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>LBT/LUCI\u00a0</td><td><em>J</em>\u00a0</td><td>23.77 \u00b1 0.37\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td><em>K</em><sub>s</sub>\u00a0</td><td>23.14 \u00b1 Magnitudes are on the AB system (Oke &amp; Gunn <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1983</a>) and have been corrected for extinction using the Schlegel, Finkbeiner &amp; Davis (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib57\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib57\" data-open=\"bib57\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1998</a>) maps. No attempt has been made to deblend the foreground and background galaxies.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow fluxes measured through elliptical apertures (<span class=\"monospace\">SExtractor</span> MAG_AUTO).</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Source<span 0.30\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td><em>i</em>\u00a0</td><td>22.89 \u00b1 0.02\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>LBT/LUCI\u00a0</td><td><em>J</em>\u00a0</td><td>23.77 \u00b1 0.37\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td><em>K</em><sub>s</sub>\u00a0</td><td>23.14 \u00b1 0.25\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Spitzer\u00a0</td><td>3.6 \u03bcm\u00a0</td><td>22.37 \u00b1 0.09\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>4.5 \u03bcm\u00a0</td><td>22.03 \u00b1 0.06\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-tblf1\"></span><div content-id=\"tblf1\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Notes</em>. Magnitudes are on the AB system (Oke &amp; Gunn <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1983</a>) and have been corrected for extinction using the Schlegel, Finkbeiner &amp; Davis (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib57\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib57\" data-open=\"bib57\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1998</a>) maps. No attempt has been made to deblend the foreground and background galaxies.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/118502064\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=118502065 id=\"118502065\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-2>2.2 MMT observations</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We first obtained a spectrum of J1414+5446 on UT 2012 May 28 using the Red Channel spectrograph on the MMT 6.5-m telescope. The object was placed in a 1 arcsec \u00d7 180 arcsec longslit after a blind offset from a nearby reference star and dispersed with a 270\u00a0mm<sup>\u22121</sup> grating centred at 7500\u00c5, providing coverage from 5700 \u00c5 to 9100 \u00c5 at a resolution of <em>R</em> \u223c640. Two 20-min exposures in good conditions with 0.9 arcsec seeing were obtained.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The spectrum was reduced using standard IRAF tasks. Wavelength calibration was obtained from an HeNeAr lamp and then refined using night sky lines in the science spectra. Flux calibration was obtained from an observation of PG1708+602 taken shortly after the science observations.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We obtained a higher resolution spectrum of J1414+5446 on 2013 May 18 using the 1200\u20139000 grating on Red Channel. The spectrum extends from 7240 \u00c5 to 8050 \u00c5 at a dispersion of 0.8 \u00c5pix<sup>\u22121</sup>. We measured a resolution of <em>R</em> \u223c3000 at \u223c7800 \u00c5 from unblended night sky lines. We obtained two exposures of 1800s each in \u223c1.2 arcsec seeing at position angle (PA) of 157.6 deg. The spectra were processed with the same routines as for the low-dispersion spectrum, using observations of standard HZ44 for flux calibration. The flux calibration is highly uncertain, given the variable conditions during the observing period and the likelihood of slight mis-centreing of the object in the slit due to the use of a blind offset for acquisition.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=118502069 id=\"118502069\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-3>2.3 LBT observations</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In this section, we describe imaging and spectroscopy of J1414+5446 obtained with the 2 \u00d7 8.4-m Large Binocular Telescope (LBT). This includes optical imaging and medium-resolution spectroscopy with the MODS1 instrument (Pogge et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib53\" data-open=\"bib53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>) and near-infrared imaging with the LUCI1 instrument (Seifert et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib58\" data-open=\"bib58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>).</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=118502071 id=\"118502071\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-3-1>2.3.1 LUCI1 imaging</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We obtained <em>J</em>-band imaging with LUCI1 on 2013 March 5 in poor, non-photometric conditions with variable cloud extinction and \u223c1.4 arcsec seeing. A total of 60\u00a0min of integration was accumulated through dithered 6 \u00d7 20 s individual exposures. Further LUCI1 observations were obtained on 2015 April 6\u20137 using the <em>K</em><sub>s</sub> bandpass. The night of 2015 April 6 was non-photometric with passing clouds with 0.7 arcsec seeing. The total exposure time was 36\u00a0min after rejecting a few integrations that were strongly affected by low transparency. The following night was photometric and the total exposure time was 44\u00a0min with seeing of 0.8 arcsec.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The LUCI1 data were processed in a standard fashion using IRAF tasks, incorporating dark current subtraction, flat-fields generated from combining the science images, and running sky subtraction. The processed images for each night were then shifted and combined to construct the final images. Individual images were weighted based on the transparency (<em>T</em>), seeing (FWHM), and sky background (<em>B</em>) as <em>T</em>/(FWHM<sup>2</sup> + <em>B</em>) when combining, where each weight term is relative to the maximum value of the given parameter. Finally, the combined images were binned by a factor of 2 along each axis to a resulting pixel scale of 0.24 arcsec. Object detection was performed on the binned images using <span class=\"monospace\">SExtractor</span> (Bertin &amp; Arnouts <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib6\" data-open=\"bib6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>), and astrometric solutions were obtained by matching well-detected objects to the CFHTLS-W3 <em>i</em>-band catalogue.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We used 2MASS (Skrutskie et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib61\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib61\" data-open=\"bib61\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>) stars detected within the field to determine the image zero points. The calibration accuracy is severely limited by the small number of 2MASS stars available \u2013 only 5 (2) in the <em>J</em> (<em>K</em><sub>s</sub>) band. We checked the LUCI photometry against red sequence galaxies selected from the images, most of which lie at the foreground cluster redshift. Comparing our colours to a template red galaxy spectrum at this redshift, we find shifts of \u223c0.25 and \u223c0.13 mag in the <em>J</em> and <em>K</em><sub>s</sub> bands, respectively. We apply these shifts and add an equal amount of error in quadrature to the photometry in order to capture the calibration uncertainty.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=118502075 id=\"118502075\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-3-2>2.3.2 MODS1 imaging</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We observed J1414+5446 with the imaging mode of MODS1 on 2014 May 31. MODS1 includes a dichroic for observing blue and red wavelengths simultaneously. The field-of-view in the 3K \u00d7 3K imaging mode is 6 arcmin across, and the pixel scale for the blue (red) channel is 0<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${^{\\prime\\prime}_{.}}$|</span>120 (0<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${^{\\prime\\prime}_{.}}$|</span>123). We used the <em>g</em> filter in the blue channel and the <em>i</em> filter in the red channel and obtained six dithered exposures with individual integration times of 5\u00a0min. Conditions were clear and photometric, and the seeing measured from the images is 0<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${^{\\prime\\prime}_{.}}$|</span>6 in the <em>i</em> band and 0<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${^{\\prime\\prime}_{.}}$|</span>75 in the <em>g</em> band.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Standard methods were employed to process the optical images, using custom Python routines. A series of bias images were median-combined to create a master bias. Pixel flat-fields were generated from a series of exposures taken with an internal lamp. The final flat-field correction consisted of a stack of the pixel flats, as well as an illumination correction derived from twilight sky flat images. After applying the bias and flat-field corrections, the individual science images were processed and combined using <span class=\"monospace\">Scamp</span> (Bertin <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>) to obtain initial astrometric solutions and <span class=\"monospace\">SWarp</span> (Bertin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib7\" data-open=\"bib7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>) to co-add the images. Sky subtraction was enabled when combining with <span class=\"monospace\">SWarp</span> as the sky level varied substantially over the course of the observations. The images were combined in two iterations; the first iteration produced a reference image from which cosmic rays and other defects in individual images were identified and masked prior to the final co-addition.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We produced two sets of final images in each band. The first are in the native pixel scale and footprint of each detector. The second are matched to the <em>g</em>-band pixel scale and aligned using <span class=\"monospace\">SWarp</span>. We derive object catalogues from all images using <span class=\"monospace\">SExtractor</span>; for the pair of aligned images, we used dual-image mode with the <em>i</em>-band image for detection. Finally, we registered the images to the CFHTLS astrometry and determined the photometric zero point by matching to stars in the CFHTLS catalogues. The MODS <em>g</em> and <em>i</em> filters are slightly bluer than the corresponding CFHT filters; we thus corrected for a slight tilt (\u2009\u22721 per cent over the range of interest) between the two photometric systems in order to place the LBT magnitudes on the CFHT system. The calibrated photometry from the dual-image mode catalogues is listed in Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> and postage stamp images are displayed in Fig. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>. The primary result from this imaging is confirmation of the <em>g</em>-band detection in the CFHTLS.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=118502079 id=\"118502079\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-3-3>2.3.3 MODS1 spectroscopy</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We obtained optical spectroscopy of J1414+5446 with MODS1 on three different nights. The goals of the spectroscopy were twofold. First, to obtain a deep spectrum of the high-<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span> galaxy to search for weak emission and absorption features. Secondly, we targeted the lensed arc candidates as well as cluster member galaxies in order to better constrain the lensing model. We designed three slitmasks, each of which included the J1414+5446 as a target. Two of the masks included slits for a long tangential arc (T1 in Cabanac et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib11\" data-open=\"bib11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>) and one mask included both of the candidate radial arcs (R1 and R2 in More et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib46\" data-open=\"bib46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). Details of the MODS1 observations are provided in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a> and results from the multiobject spectroscopy are described in Appendix \u00a0<a class=\"js-jumplink\" href=\"#sec6\">A</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"118502081\" scrollto-destination=\"118502081\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl2\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl2\" data-id=\"tbl2\"><span class=\"label\">Table 2.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">LBT/MODS1 multislit spectroscopic observations. The final column notes which of the lensed arc candidates described in Section <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2-3-3\"></span><a href=\"#sec2-3-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2.3.3</a> are included on each mask.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Mask ID<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>UT<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Exp. (h)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Conditions<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Notes<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>505919\u00a0</td><td>2013-04-13\u00a0</td><td>1.9\u00a0</td><td>0.8 arcsec, passing clouds\u00a0</td><td>T1\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>523405\u00a0</td><td>2015-03-25\u00a0</td><td>3.8\u00a0</td><td>1.0 arcsec, clear\u00a0</td><td>T1\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>510122\u00a0</td><td>2015-03-26\u00a0</td><td>3.7\u00a0</td><td>0.6\u20131.0 arcsec, cloudy\u00a0</td><td>R1, R2\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th>Mask ID<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>UT<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Exp. (h)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Conditions<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Notes<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>505919\u00a0</td><td>2013-04-13\u00a0</td><td>1.9\u00a0</td><td>0.8 arcsec, passing clouds\u00a0</td><td>T1\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>523405\u00a0</td><td>2015-03-25\u00a0</td><td>3.8\u00a0</td><td>1.0 arcsec, clear\u00a0</td><td>T1\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>510122\u00a0</td><td>2015-03-26\u00a0</td><td>3.7\u00a0</td><td>0.6\u20131.0 arcsec, cloudy\u00a0</td><td>R1, R2\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/118502081\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl2\" data-id=\"tbl2\"><span class=\"label\">Table 2.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">LBT/MODS1 multislit spectroscopic observations. The final column notes which of the lensed arc candidates described in Section <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2-3-3\"></span><a href=\"#sec2-3-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2.3.3</a> are included on each mask.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Mask ID<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>UT<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Exp. (h)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Conditions<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Notes<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>505919\u00a0</td><td>2013-04-13\u00a0</td><td>1.9\u00a0</td><td>0.8 arcsec, passing clouds\u00a0</td><td>T1\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>523405\u00a0</td><td>2015-03-25\u00a0</td><td>3.8\u00a0</td><td>1.0 arcsec, clear\u00a0</td><td>T1\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>510122\u00a0</td><td>2015-03-26\u00a0</td><td>3.7\u00a0</td><td>0.6\u20131.0 arcsec, cloudy\u00a0</td><td>R1, R2\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th>Mask ID<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>UT<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Exp. (h)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Conditions<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Notes<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>505919\u00a0</td><td>2013-04-13\u00a0</td><td>1.9\u00a0</td><td>0.8 arcsec, passing clouds\u00a0</td><td>T1\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>523405\u00a0</td><td>2015-03-25\u00a0</td><td>3.8\u00a0</td><td>1.0 arcsec, clear\u00a0</td><td>T1\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>510122\u00a0</td><td>2015-03-26\u00a0</td><td>3.7\u00a0</td><td>0.6\u20131.0 arcsec, cloudy\u00a0</td><td>R1, R2\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/118502081\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">All observations employed the dual grating mode of MODS1 for complete wavelength coverage from 3200 \u00c5 to 1 \u03bcm. The slits for J1414+5446 were 14\u201320 arcsec in length while the slits for the galaxy targets were 7\u201310 arcsec; all slits had a width of 1 arcsec. The resolution in the blue channel (up to 6000 \u00c5) is <em>R</em> \u223c1100 and in the red channel (starting at 5000 \u00c5) is \u223c1400.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><span class=\"monospace\"><span class=\"small-caps\">modsidl</span></span><span class=\"monospace\"><span class=\"small-caps\">modsccdred</span></span>The spectra were processed with Version 2.0 of the software, and version 0.2p1 of the <span class=\"monospace\"><span class=\"small-caps\">modsidl</span></span> spectral reduction pipeline.<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn1\" data-open=\"fn1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">1</a></sup> Individual frames were bias-subtracted and then flat-fielded using a series of internal lamp calibrations. Wavelength calibration was provided by a combination of internal arcs and has an rms &lt;0.1\u00c5. Flux calibration was obtained through observations of the spectrophotometric standard stars Feige 34 and BD+33d2642 acquired in the same night. The individual science frames were sky-subtracted and 1D spectra were extracted using . The <span class=\"small-caps\"><span class=\"monospace\">modsidl</span></span> implementation uses boxcar extraction; we constructed model profiles using stars included in the slit masks and used these models to perform optimal extraction (Horne <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib29\" data-open=\"bib29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1986</a>), with a significant gain in <em>S</em>/<em>N</em> compared to the boxcar-extracted spectra. The individual spectra from each night were combined with inverse-variance weighting, scaling the Ly\u00a0\u03b1 flux measured from each image to account for transparency variations. Finally, the spectra from the three nights were combined to produce the final MODS spectrum shown in Fig. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>.Before combining, a correction to the flux calibration for the spectra from each mask was determined by comparing the spectrophotometry obtained for the field galaxies to their photometry in the CFHTLS. The total exposure time is \u223c9.4\u00a0h; however, two of the nights were affected by passing clouds and we estimate the effective exposure time to be \u223c7\u00a0h.</p>                        <a id=\"118502084\" scrollto-destination=\"118502084\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/1/10.1093_mnras_sty1411/1/m_sty1411fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611465923&amp;Signature=0n56UTA9aj8zuFPNJyylaMflpvmQI8s-4UOo-QLDJKK2-5VNTrc6~Y5JehcoecbE9O7PMntv3EwCTS4TVgD2-OGTyC52e5RzkXL205c~gyvnmLf7S1pTpy2hOJDAdrRo8OXimVY0XZYMKl19zm5BYRkQQgvBS4G6wiFAL34tr21xXzcWqH0ehPHfFKw4XRAs0DxV925kMQfLpCerb6o-8riB42EOo8jKsyaZvkOLBfUYIl3SVpu-wpVLRSGB8BW-bPVxJqXWsJeITc24v14eB0wl64ZnUYGBWNP1zuBJm50uQ~M1FrZXLTp3aVaLjHKOHBnOgsEHsfg2tJ34z0T7YA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"LBT/MODS1 spectrum of J1414+5446, dominated by the strong Ly\u00a0\u03b1 emission feature. The inset panel highlights the continuum emission detected at \u223c2\u03c3pix\u22121 redward of the Ly\u00a0\u03b1 emission (the continuum fit is indicated by the dashed blue line and the error spectrum by the solid orange line). Flux is also detected at \u223c1\u03c3pix\u22121 blueward of Ly\u00a0\u03b1, although there is a clear spectral break at the wavelength Ly\u00a0\u03b1. Flux is also detected at \u223c1\u03c3pix<sup>\u22121</sup> blueward of Ly\u00a0\u03b1, although there is a clear spectral break at the wavelength Ly\u00a0\u03b1.
