The inset panel highlights the continuum emission detected at \u223c2\u03c3pix<sup>\u22121</sup> redward of the Ly\u00a0\u03b1 emission (the continuum fit is indicated by the dashed blue line and the error spectrum by the solid orange line). Flux is also detected at \u223c1\u03c3pix<sup>\u22121</sup> blueward of Ly\u00a0\u03b1, although there is a clear spectral break at the wavelength Ly\u00a0\u03b1. The wavelengths of the N\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span> and C\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span> features are marked with small vertical lines and will be discussed in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4.2</a>.</p></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=118502085 id=\"118502085\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-4>2.4 <em>HST</em> imaging</h3>\r\n                    <h4 scrollto-destination=118502086 id=\"118502086\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-4-1>2.4.1 Archival WFPC2 observations</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">J1414+5446 is within the field of SL2S J141447+544703, a lensing group included in the Strong Lensing Legacy Survey (SL2S; Cabanac et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib11\" data-open=\"bib11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>). This survey identified candidate strong lenses up to <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span> \u223c1 in the CFHTLS imaging and included <em>HST</em> observations as part of a Cycle 16 SNAPSHOT program (GO #11289, PI: Kneib). The SL2S J141447+544703 field was observed with three dithered 400 s exposures using the WFPC2 instrument and the F606W bandpass. J1414+5446 is located \u223c30 arcsec from the centre of the lensing group and was well within the WFCP2 image. The F606W bandpass is entirely blueward of Ly\u00a0\u03b1 at <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span> = 5.4 and thus samples the attenuated rest-FUV continuum of the galaxy.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We processed the archival WFPC2 images using <span class=\"small-caps\">AstroDrizzle</span> ,<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn2\" data-open=\"fn2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">2</a></sup> setting pixfrac = 1.0 and drizzling to a final pixel scale of 0<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${^{\\prime\\prime}_{.}}$|</span>05. We found that the default astrometry matched the CFHT astrometry to an accuracy of &lt;0<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${^{\\prime\\prime}_{.}}$|</span>05 . J1414+5446 is clearly detected in the final WFPC2 mosaic; furthermore, on &lt;0<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${^{\\prime\\prime}_{.}}$|</span>4 scales, it resolves into up to four components (Fig. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>).</p>                        <a id=\"118502089\" scrollto-destination=\"118502089\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 4.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/1/10.1093_mnras_sty1411/1/m_sty1411fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611465923&amp;Signature=TJ7HLQdB5B0~NRu0ydA-iDYUhS83OHpn2c6KXS3wE26RSjHb3KaNYAC6d8tL~ckxMsIwKbY4SPJjgZ50euJVjJ1vDP8QHZuqMgj0EoWvk-4uJpwWbdYO1FX2q-dzsPycKwiaAa1dNJ4VH1xv8GOP2wMOlnJqJ43iC~RMXmOoG-POSSKf5ByCRHU8wHeToXfzT0VYX5GmMNs-PPbwzouL8f0hFpiosxh18q76ROnKILruY1fPG95TbY-ffWfAJz-~OXIQCBB3uInLpXadreUBAqtmi6L1K7wCZpbL8CpuiW9ZIGKI3OlZos3Pz317rGpmHPkp~QJ5qicf2Ven6sBCSA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"HST imaging of J1414+5446. The top panel displays the filter set, including the ACS ramp filter used for narrowband imaging of Ly\u00a0\u03b1 (FR782N). A model for the LAE spectrum based on its observed properties is represented by a blue line, while an Sbc template for the foreground galaxy is represented by a green dashed line. The bottom three panels present the HST images, oriented as indicated in the lower left panel. The F606W image clearly has multiple components. The labels match those in Table\u00a03. Labels C and D mark low-significance peaks in the HST image that are putative detections; in the analysis, C is modelled as both a separate component and as part of B, while D is ignored. The red plus sign marks the location of the g-band centroid obtained from the CFHT/LBT imaging. The middle panel presents the narrowband image, smoothed with a 1-pixel Gaussian and overlaid with linearly spaced contours from the F606W image. The approximate locations of the spectroscopic slits for the two MODS masks are indicated with dashed orange lines. The right-hand panel presents a colour composite constructed from the ACS and WFC3 images, where the ACS image has been convolved with a Gaussian and resampled to match the WFC3 PSF and footprint. Logarithmically spaced contours from the narrowband (Ly\u00a0\u03b1) image are overlaid in cyan lines.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1411fig4.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/118502089/sty1411fig4.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1411fig4.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"118502089\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/1/10.1093_mnras_sty1411/1/sty1411fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611465923&Signature=JbwHjjwEX3kKN3aSnOZyWCVykYaynr0WsIJ7jz7utej5wEFt2u57emaevD1k3yfuRp6BesQpo8KRhglNPgtuAuCh-I3QHHy~GOkeX0LNO5ilEXXyACX20TN3gIb7OlvCv3dp0DgzFM0qxu8~4nESmIY2tS6fcYjII3xkXh39Tj3UrhoZJ3mEuU6kE1k61492ifWv2QA2NY3GZyf5YGbfmDLbx~-yACqvQemkHsfhY8M1Or6k3OkzUjokgVQ5cV25PAoxJzE6mqqq8J~IKyDfFVMlz69iDV01-hjPrD2aB1zIzvG-~IvgQVJXEYIph05J0CknIC~ans6HrlYt3QhaaQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=118502089&ar=5026178&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1411fig4.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>HST</em> imaging of J1414+5446. The top panel displays the filter set, including the ACS ramp filter used for narrowband imaging of Ly\u00a0\u03b1 (FR782N). A model for the LAE spectrum based on its observed properties is represented by a blue line, while an Sbc template for the foreground galaxy is represented by a green dashed line. The bottom three panels present the <em>HST</em> images, oriented as indicated in the lower left panel. The F606W image clearly has multiple components. The labels match those in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>. Labels C and D mark low-significance peaks in the <em>HST</em> image that are putative detections; in the analysis, C is modelled as both a separate component and as part of B, while D is ignored. The red plus sign marks the location of the <em>g</em>-band centroid obtained from the CFHT/LBT imaging. The middle panel presents the narrowband image, smoothed with a 1-pixel Gaussian and overlaid with linearly spaced contours from the F606W image. The approximate locations of the spectroscopic slits for the two MODS masks are indicated with dashed orange lines. The right-hand panel presents a colour composite constructed from the ACS and WFC3 images, where the ACS image has been convolved with a Gaussian and resampled to match the WFC3 PSF and footprint. Logarithmically spaced contours from the narrowband (Ly\u00a0\u03b1) image are overlaid in cyan lines.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 4.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/1/10.1093_mnras_sty1411/1/m_sty1411fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611465923&amp;Signature=TJ7HLQdB5B0~NRu0ydA-iDYUhS83OHpn2c6KXS3wE26RSjHb3KaNYAC6d8tL~ckxMsIwKbY4SPJjgZ50euJVjJ1vDP8QHZuqMgj0EoWvk-4uJpwWbdYO1FX2q-dzsPycKwiaAa1dNJ4VH1xv8GOP2wMOlnJqJ43iC~RMXmOoG-POSSKf5ByCRHU8wHeToXfzT0VYX5GmMNs-PPbwzouL8f0hFpiosxh18q76ROnKILruY1fPG95TbY-ffWfAJz-~OXIQCBB3uInLpXadreUBAqtmi6L1K7wCZpbL8CpuiW9ZIGKI3OlZos3Pz317rGpmHPkp~QJ5qicf2Ven6sBCSA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"HST imaging of J1414+5446. The top panel displays the filter set, including the ACS ramp filter used for narrowband imaging of Ly\u00a0\u03b1 (FR782N). A model for the LAE spectrum based on its observed properties is represented by a blue line, while an Sbc template for the foreground galaxy is represented by a green dashed line. The bottom three panels present the HST images, oriented as indicated in the lower left panel. The F606W image clearly has multiple components. The labels match those in Table\u00a03. Labels C and D mark low-significance peaks in the HST image that are putative detections; in the analysis, C is modelled as both a separate component and as part of B, while D is ignored. The red plus sign marks the location of the g-band centroid obtained from the CFHT/LBT imaging. The middle panel presents the narrowband image, smoothed with a 1-pixel Gaussian and overlaid with linearly spaced contours from the F606W image. The approximate locations of the spectroscopic slits for the two MODS masks are indicated with dashed orange lines. The right-hand panel presents a colour composite constructed from the ACS and WFC3 images, where the ACS image has been convolved with a Gaussian and resampled to match the WFC3 PSF and footprint. Logarithmically spaced contours from the narrowband (Ly\u00a0\u03b1) image are overlaid in cyan lines.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1411fig4.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/118502089/sty1411fig4.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1411fig4.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"118502089\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/1/10.1093_mnras_sty1411/1/sty1411fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611465923&Signature=JbwHjjwEX3kKN3aSnOZyWCVykYaynr0WsIJ7jz7utej5wEFt2u57emaevD1k3yfuRp6BesQpo8KRhglNPgtuAuCh-I3QHHy~GOkeX0LNO5ilEXXyACX20TN3gIb7OlvCv3dp0DgzFM0qxu8~4nESmIY2tS6fcYjII3xkXh39Tj3UrhoZJ3mEuU6kE1k61492ifWv2QA2NY3GZyf5YGbfmDLbx~-yACqvQemkHsfhY8M1Or6k3OkzUjokgVQ5cV25PAoxJzE6mqqq8J~IKyDfFVMlz69iDV01-hjPrD2aB1zIzvG-~IvgQVJXEYIph05J0CknIC~ans6HrlYt3QhaaQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=118502089&ar=5026178&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1411fig4.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>HST</em> imaging of J1414+5446. The top panel displays the filter set, including the ACS ramp filter used for narrowband imaging of Ly\u00a0\u03b1 (FR782N). A model for the LAE spectrum based on its observed properties is represented by a blue line, while an Sbc template for the foreground galaxy is represented by a green dashed line. The bottom three panels present the <em>HST</em> images, oriented as indicated in the lower left panel. The F606W image clearly has multiple components. The labels match those in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>. Labels C and D mark low-significance peaks in the <em>HST</em> image that are putative detections; in the analysis, C is modelled as both a separate component and as part of B, while D is ignored. The red plus sign marks the location of the <em>g</em>-band centroid obtained from the CFHT/LBT imaging. The middle panel presents the narrowband image, smoothed with a 1-pixel Gaussian and overlaid with linearly spaced contours from the F606W image. The approximate locations of the spectroscopic slits for the two MODS masks are indicated with dashed orange lines. The right-hand panel presents a colour composite constructed from the ACS and WFC3 images, where the ACS image has been convolved with a Gaussian and resampled to match the WFC3 PSF and footprint. Logarithmically spaced contours from the narrowband (Ly\u00a0\u03b1) image are overlaid in cyan lines.</p></div></div>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=118502090 id=\"118502090\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-4-2>2.4.2 Cycle 22 ACS/WFC3 observations</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We obtained Cycle 22 imaging of J1414+5446 on 2015 November 14 with ACS and WFC3 (GO #13762, PI: McGreer). We employed three bandpasses to probe the rest-UV continuum from the high-<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span> galaxy: ACS/F850LP and WFC3-IR F125W and F160W, spanning \u223c1400\u20132600 \u00c5 rest frame. We also used the ACS ramp filter FR782N centred at 7816\u00c5 to capture the Ly\u00a0\u03b1 emission. The total exposure times were 813 s for the ramp filter, 1011 s for ACS/F850LP, and 1359 s each for the two WFC3 bands. All observations used a standard three-point dither pattern. We imposed an orientation constraint on the ACS observations to ensure that the F850LP image would include the brightest cluster galaxy (BCG) and the lensed arcs.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Images were processed using <span class=\"small-caps\">AstroDrizzle</span>. A first-pass drizzled ACS/F850LP image was registered to the CFHT <em>i</em>-band astrometry as with the WFPC2 image. The F850LP and FR782N images were obtained in the same orbit with the same orientation and field centre, thus the updated astrometry was propagated back into all the ACS images using the <span class=\"small-caps\">tweakshifts</span> routine before generating a final mosaic. We used pixfrac = 0.8 and a scale of 0<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${^{\\prime\\prime}_{.}}$|</span>03 for the output pixel grid (Koekemoer et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib37\" data-open=\"bib37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>). The WFC3 images were processed in a similar fashion but with a final scale of 0<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${^{\\prime\\prime}_{.}}$|</span>06. Comparing object centroids between the various <em>HST</em> bands, we find that they are aligned to \u22720<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${^{\\prime\\prime}_{.}}$|</span>05 accuracy.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We generated empirical PSF models for the broadband images from stars within the field using IRAF DAOPHOT tasks. The narrowband image has only a single-stellar object with sufficient signal-to-noise to serve as a PSF reference. J1414+5446 is well detected in all <em>HST</em> images, including the narrowband (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>). We will discuss multicomponent fits to the <em>HST</em> images in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.2</a>.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=118502094 id=\"118502094\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-5>2.5 Spitzer Cycle 9 observations</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Mid-IR observations have a key role in characterizing high redshift galaxies by providing constraints on the SED redward of the Balmer break. Compared to rest-UV wavelengths, rest frame optical observations better probe the star formation history, stellar mass, and dust extinction, and thus are essential to forming a more complete picture of the stellar population.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">J1414+5446 was observed with the IRAC camera on Spitzer during the Warm Mission (GO #90195, PI: McGreer). The observations consisted of a single Astronomical Observation Request with integrations in the 3.6-\u03bcm and 4.5-\u03bcm channels totalling 1800 s in each channel using a standard dither pattern. We estimate a point source sensitivity of \u223c1.5 \u03bcJy (5 \u03c3) from both the 3.6-\u03bcm and 4.5-\u03bcm images. J1414+5446 is clearly detected in both images, with total fluxes of <em>f</em><sub>3.6</sub> = (4.08 \u00b1 0.33) \u03bcJy and <em>f</em><sub>4.5</sub> = (5.58 \u00b1 0.30) \u03bcJy measured through aperture photometry (<span class=\"monospace\">SExtractor</span> MAG_AUTO).</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=118502097 id=\"118502097\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3>3 IMAGE MODELLING</h2>\r\n                    <h3 scrollto-destination=118502098 id=\"118502098\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-1>3.1 Foreground galaxy</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The <em>g</em>-band detections, and marginal <em>u</em>-band detection, are somewhat puzzling. Both bands are completely blueward of the Lyman Limit at this redshift (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>) and thus will be subject to Lyman continuum absorption. The co-moving mean free path of Lyman Limit photons at <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span> = 5.4 is <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\sim }60 h_{70}^{-1}$|</span> Mpc (Worseck et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib77\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib77\" data-open=\"bib77\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>); hence, the probability that significant flux would transmit through the intergalactic medium (IGM) from a high-redshift galaxy into these bands is exceedingly low. We used Monte Carlo simulations<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn3\" data-open=\"fn3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">3</a></sup> of Ly\u00a0\u03b1 forest transmission spectra at <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span> = 5.4 to examine the possibility that an IGM sightline would be sufficiently transparent to allow detectable <em>g</em>-band flux from J1414+5446. After generating a model galaxy spectrum based on the photometry at longer wavelengths (conservatively assuming a blue UV slope of \u03b2<sub>\u03bb</sub> = \u22121.5 and an escape fraction of unity), we find that none of the 2000 simulated sightlines had <em>g</em> &lt; 28, compared to the measured fluxes of \u223c26.5. We conclude that the flux at blue wavelengths must be due to a foreground interloper.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">An interesting question is whether the interloper would have impeded selection of the high redshift galaxy according to standard colour selection methods. The criteria employed for our quasar selection are very similar to those used to select \u2018dropout\u2019 galaxies. As noted previously, we did not reject this object as the <em>g</em>-band photometry in the catalogues we used for selection reported a &lt;2.5 \u03c3 detection. However, a stricter cut on the bluer bands may have rejected this object. In addition, the faint fluxes in the bluer bands are sufficient to affect photometric redshift estimation. The CFHTLS photometric redshift catalogues of Ilbert et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>) and Coupon et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>) place J1414+5446 at <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span> = 0.75, with a 68\u2009 per\u2009cent confidence interval of 0.68 &lt; <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span> &lt; 0.89. The fluxes in the blue optical bands result in this high-redshift galaxy having roughly similar colours to the red galaxies at the cluster redshift, and thus it could be easily overlooked by broadband colour selection.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=118502101 id=\"118502101\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-2>3.2 <em>HST</em> image decomposition</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Interpretation of the high-resolution images from <em>HST</em> is not straightforward. The WFPC2 F606W image (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>) shows the largest degree of apparent structure, with up to four individual emission peaks. On the other hand, the narrowband image has only a single prominent source. The F850LP image is dominated by a bright source that coincides with the narrowband detection, with the addition of a faint source to the SW. The WFC3 images appear to have two components of roughly equal strength, roughly matching the morphology of the F850LP image.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">It is not obvious how to associate individual components across all of the emission bands. The narrow band image pinpoints the location of the Ly\u00a0\u03b1 emission from the <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span> = 5.4 galaxy. Emission peaks at this position are present in all bands, including F606W (see the component labelled \u2018A\u2019 in Fig. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>). On the other hand, the foreground galaxy should dominate the <em>g</em>-band emission. The centroid obtained from the ground-based CFHT/LBT <em>g</em>-band imaging most closely aligns with the brightest component found in the F606W image (labeled B in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>). This position is also well matched to the extended emission to the SW of the Ly\u00a0\u03b1 peak in the <em>HST</em> images.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We implemented a multiband-fitting procedure in python that allows for an arbitrary number of point source (hereafter PSF) and extended object components to be included in a given model. These components are then rendered into images for each <em>HST</em> band by convolving the model with empirical PSFs derived from field stars. The extended components are based on S\u00e9rsic profiles. The rendered images are then compared to the data with a \u03c7<sup>2</sup> statistic, summing the contributions from all bands. A minimization routine (the Nelder\u2013Mead gradient search implemented in Scipy) is then used to find the best-fitting set of parameters. During this procedure, we exclude the narrowband image as it probes only the Ly\u00a0\u03b1 emission from the high-<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span> galaxy, which may have a different morphology than the continuum emission.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We then experimented with a number of configurations to fit the individual emission components in the <em>HST</em> images. Unresolved components are modelled with three parameters (<em>x</em>, <em>y</em>, and flux), while S\u00e9rsic profiles have a total of seven parameters (<em>x</em>, <em>y</em>, flux, effective radius, S\u00e9rsic index, ellipticity, and PA). Given the large number of parameters and the substantial blending apparent in the images (leading to degeneracies in the fits), we reduce the number of parameters by making some simplifying assumptions. We fixed the position of the Ly\u00a0\u03b1-emitting component (A) to the position obtained from the F850LP image, where it is cleanly detected at high significance. We required the positions of any additional S\u00e9rsic components to be identical across all bands. Finally, we found that fitting the sky background was unnecessary and thus simply removed a median value from each band using nearby sky pixels.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Our fiducial configuration (left-hand panel of Fig. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>) consists of a single PSF component (A) aligned with the bright source in the F850LP image, and a S\u00e9rsic component (B). We required the PA of the S\u00e9rsic component to be identical in all bands and fixed the index to <em>n</em> = 1.1 and the ellipticity to 0.28 in all bands. The latter values were found by allowing those two parameters to vary while holding other parameters fixed. The effective radius is allowed to vary between bands in order to account for morphological variations with wavelength. This model provides a reasonably good fit to the data, with <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\chi ^2_\\nu = 1.22 (16377/13426)$|\u2060</span>. The best-fitting effective radius is 0.7 arcsec \u00b1 0.1 arcsec in the F606W band and 0.9 arcsec \u00b1 0.03 arcsec in the other bands. In this model, we assume that the PSF component corresponds to all of the flux from the high-<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span> galaxy, and the S\u00e9rsic component is contributed entirely by a low-<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span> interloper.</p>                        <a id=\"118502107\" scrollto-destination=\"118502107\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig5\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 5.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/1/10.1093_mnras_sty1411/1/m_sty1411fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611465923&amp;Signature=VQqW0jNHZN2luM1lkIWfwUJmnrDUDlmByWhKl018hISts5OfzMdflug8dAibTo-~rsKv~G-qblKqIcNvEUGX6n~G3pZJSy3cOKZikltLsi5eDtlUA11RfQzWVy9FXJ6DsDzYYc0IRzJbuFlzzgdty0gDag3frUKvEbspyF0YMvK7KXUvdUH23eOpj0KLLVBU1jBYSoevGjoOHYQHRgy34CyLq9ePnFpXL2P9C2YG3k580Ze-agBrRcKhBJ0pVICAhclmsw6MjMb887JGWMNofM~cvmPP6jQXsBUVAS11~ambfaW4YU1jB7tX1S6LD8OOhTDjsqA1DesoyHnKsGYfIA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Image models for the two (left-hand panel) and three (right-hand panel) component fits to the HST images. The background image is from WFPC2/F606W, with a pixel scale of 0.05 arcsec. The dashed lines are linearly spaced surface brightness contours from the F606W image. Positions of the individual components are labelled and marked with plus signs. Extended components (S\u00e9rsic profiles) are represented with an ellipse based on the fitted parameters (displayed without PSF convolution), with a radius of reff/5. The size of the image cutouts is 0.4 arcsec and the orientation is N through E, as in Fig. 4.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1411fig5.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/118502107/sty1411fig5.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1411fig5.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"118502107\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/1/10.1093_mnras_sty1411/1/sty1411fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611465923&Signature=UznJFdoxU~-EDhA6r7VmjZ0oI6IZ5gZ-twIPIARY2OzctuTosyLl7USiE1R3K--OOiO2CTBJ9zFy8JLmyFa-BnOkOIYxUXCHyNF9SzatZNhBEZbrhl91peAdxZYeQgMt8oVVW70Dpsrx7GjNKh-EtYiqUO7AskbcyCd2IO8jpOhk0nb8ffaZ36E9SoSOx8zq1uQjXiaXgvEaNG6OfIQL~JGCkZmivK4lCGiT3Zc4YlV~81BBmfYrbQwFX6AAY5gKOUS89h6FnZJa7msc7Ny~HPC7fNxE5oEJooWAL7l3rEup8N1SUhkHT4NSyVBWuiqKAbxmQ~9M4kRIrBm737yf6w__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=118502107&ar=5026178&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1411fig5.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Image models for the two (left-hand panel) and three (right-hand panel) component fits to the <em>HST</em> images. The background image is from WFPC2/F606W, with a pixel scale of 0.05 arcsec. The dashed lines are linearly spaced surface brightness contours from the F606W image. Positions of the individual components are labelled and marked with plus signs. Extended components (S\u00e9rsic profiles) are represented with an ellipse based on the fitted parameters (displayed without PSF convolution), with a radius of <em>r</em><sub>eff</sub>/5. The size of the image cutouts is 0.4 arcsec and the orientation is N through E, as in Fig. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig5\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 5.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/1/10.1093_mnras_sty1411/1/m_sty1411fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611465923&amp;Signature=VQqW0jNHZN2luM1lkIWfwUJmnrDUDlmByWhKl018hISts5OfzMdflug8dAibTo-~rsKv~G-qblKqIcNvEUGX6n~G3pZJSy3cOKZikltLsi5eDtlUA11RfQzWVy9FXJ6DsDzYYc0IRzJbuFlzzgdty0gDag3frUKvEbspyF0YMvK7KXUvdUH23eOpj0KLLVBU1jBYSoevGjoOHYQHRgy34CyLq9ePnFpXL2P9C2YG3k580Ze-agBrRcKhBJ0pVICAhclmsw6MjMb887JGWMNofM~cvmPP6jQXsBUVAS11~ambfaW4YU1jB7tX1S6LD8OOhTDjsqA1DesoyHnKsGYfIA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Image models for the two (left-hand panel) and three (right-hand panel) component fits to the HST images. The background image is from WFPC2/F606W, with a pixel scale of 0.05 arcsec. The dashed lines are linearly spaced surface brightness contours from the F606W image. Positions of the individual components are labelled and marked with plus signs. Extended components (S\u00e9rsic profiles) are represented with an ellipse based on the fitted parameters (displayed without PSF convolution), with a radius of reff/5. The size of the image cutouts is 0.4 arcsec and the orientation is N through E, as in Fig. 4.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1411fig5.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/118502107/sty1411fig5.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1411fig5.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"118502107\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/1/10.1093_mnras_sty1411/1/sty1411fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611465923&Signature=UznJFdoxU~-EDhA6r7VmjZ0oI6IZ5gZ-twIPIARY2OzctuTosyLl7USiE1R3K--OOiO2CTBJ9zFy8JLmyFa-BnOkOIYxUXCHyNF9SzatZNhBEZbrhl91peAdxZYeQgMt8oVVW70Dpsrx7GjNKh-EtYiqUO7AskbcyCd2IO8jpOhk0nb8ffaZ36E9SoSOx8zq1uQjXiaXgvEaNG6OfIQL~JGCkZmivK4lCGiT3Zc4YlV~81BBmfYrbQwFX6AAY5gKOUS89h6FnZJa7msc7Ny~HPC7fNxE5oEJooWAL7l3rEup8N1SUhkHT4NSyVBWuiqKAbxmQ~9M4kRIrBm737yf6w__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=118502107&ar=5026178&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1411fig5.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Image models for the two (left-hand panel) and three (right-hand panel) component fits to the <em>HST</em> images. The background image is from WFPC2/F606W, with a pixel scale of 0.05 arcsec. The dashed lines are linearly spaced surface brightness contours from the F606W image. Positions of the individual components are labelled and marked with plus signs. Extended components (S\u00e9rsic profiles) are represented with an ellipse based on the fitted parameters (displayed without PSF convolution), with a radius of <em>r</em><sub>eff</sub>/5. The size of the image cutouts is 0.4 arcsec and the orientation is N through E, as in Fig. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">In the F606W image, the SW component is highly asymmetric, with a strong peak and extended emission to the east. We consider the possibility that this emission represents a separate component by constructing a model with three components, where all components are represented by S\u00e9rsic profiles (right-hand panel of Fig. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>). The initial positions and fluxes were obtained from simple Gaussian fits to the individual peaks in the F606W image. We fixed the positions of all components to their initial positions and also fixed the S\u00e9rsic profiles to have zero ellipticity and required that the effective radii and S\u00e9rsic indices were identical across all bands. Although the Ly\u00a0\u03b1-emitting component is modelled with a S\u00e9rsic profile rather than a PSF as before, the best-fitting effective radius is \u223c0.1 arcsec, indicating that the source is at best marginally resolved in the broadband images. Components B and C both have <em>r</em><sub>e</sub> \u2248 0.4 \u2009arcsec \u2009and the best-fitting S\u00e9rsic indices are rather flat (<em>n</em> \u2272 1). The fit is improved compared to the two-component model: <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\chi ^2_\\nu = 1.20 (16060/13423)$|\u2060</span>. The addition of three parameters is statistically significant according to the Aikake Information Criteria (\u0394AIC \u2248 300). However, splitting the fluxes between the B and C components results in large photometric uncertainties, thus it is difficult to reliably constrain the contribution from each component.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Furthermore, the three-component fit has more ambiguity in its interpretation. Associating component B with the foreground galaxy remains clear, but the second component (C) could either be in the foreground or at high-<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|\u2060</span>, i.e. it could be continuum emission from the high-<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span> galaxy without associated Ly\u00a0\u03b1 emission, as is often observed (Jiang et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Pirzkal et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib50\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib50\" data-open=\"bib50\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>; Venemans et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib71\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib71\" data-open=\"bib71\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>). We consider the latter interpretation to be less likely, as this would imply relatively bright emission in a very blue band (<em>V</em><sub>606</sub> \u2248 25.9) along with relatively faint emission in the rest-UV continuum (<em>J</em><sub>125</sub> \u2248 25.9), compared to <em>V</em><sub>606</sub> = 27.7 and <em>Y</em><sub>125</sub> = 23.7 for the Ly\u00a0\u03b1-emitting component. In order to be more conservative, we adopt the two-component model to interpret the <em>HST</em> data.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=118502110 id=\"118502110\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-3>3.3 Narrowband Ly\u00a0\u03b1 imaging</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The ACS/FR782N band was selected to map the spatial extent of the Ly\u00a0\u03b1 emission from the <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span> = 5.4 galaxy with the resolution available from <em>HST</em>. The bandwidth of the ramp filter is \u223c150 \u00c5, fully encompassing the extent of the Ly\u00a0\u03b1 emission from spectroscopy (\u223c70 \u00c5, Fig. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>).The narrowband image is presented in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>. As discussed in the previous section, the single narrowband detection is also well detected in the broadbands redward of the Ly\u00a0\u03b1 line. Fitting a power law to the F850LP, F125W, and F160W measurements (Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>), we obtain a slope of \u03b2<sub>\u03bb</sub> = \u22122.58 \u00b1 0.03.</p>                        <a id=\"118502112\" scrollto-destination=\"118502112\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl3\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl3\" data-id=\"tbl3\"><span class=\"label\">Table 3.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Photometry obtained from multiband fitting to <em>HST</em> images, with the exception of FR782N, which is obtained from aperture photometry using <span class=\"monospace\">SExtractor</span> MAG_AUTO.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Component<span class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th>Component<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>(\u0394(\u03b1), \u0394(\u03b4))<span 0.18\u00a0</td><td>20.79 \u00b1 0.04\u00a0</td><td>23.64 \u00b1 0.02\u00a0</td><td>23.84 \u00b1 0.01\u00a0</td><td>23.95 \u00b1 0.01\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Sers(B+C)\u00a0</td><td>(\u22120.103, colspan=\"6\">Three-component model\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Sers(A)\u00a0</td><td>(+0.000,+0.000)\u00a0</td><td>27.27 \u00b1 0.89\u00a0</td><td>20.79 \u00b1 0.04\u00a0</td><td>23.54 \u00b1 0.02\u00a0</td><td>23.71 \u00b1 0.01\u00a0</td><td>23.80 \u00b1 0.01\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Sers(B)\u00a0</td><td>(\u22120.142, \u22120.307)\u00a0</td><td>26.47 \u00b1 0.53\u00a0</td><td>&gt;24.6\u00a0</td><td>25.27 \u00b1 0.78\u00a0</td><td>24.43 \u00b1 0.23\u00a0</td><td>24.37 \u00b1 0.40\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Sers(C)\u00a0</td><td>(+0.017, \u22120.313)\u00a0</td><td>25.87 \u00b1 0.42\u00a0</td><td>&gt;24.6\u00a0</td><td>27.27 \u00b1 5.55\u00a0</td><td>25.92 \u00b1 0.27\u00a0</td><td>25.14 \u00b1 0.21\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/118502112\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The total flux in the narrowband is <em>m</em><sub>782</sub> = 20.79 \u00b1 0.04 as measured through a 0<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${^{\\prime\\prime}_{.}}$|</span>8 aperture. Extrapolating the continuum fit to this wavelength results in EW<sub>0</sub> = 260 \u00b1 12\u00c5. One of the key aims of the <em>HST</em> program was to obtain resolved photometry of the rest-UV emission, removing the foreground contamination. As described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4.2</a>, the EW of the Ly\u00a0\u03b1 emission obtained from ground-based spectroscopy is consistent with the value from the <em>HST</em> narrowband imaging once the foreground contamination is taken into account. Thus, the large EW is robust and is slightly greater than the limit generally assumed for emission from normal stellar populations (240 \u00c5, e.g. Charlot &amp; Fall <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1993</a>; Schaerer <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>), although objects with similarly large Ly\u00a0\u03b1 EWs have been discovered in large narrowband surveys (e.g. Hashimoto et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib28\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib28\" data-open=\"bib28\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Shibuya et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The narrowband image contains a single-stellar object with sufficient <em>S</em>/<em>N</em> to characterize the PSF. Comparing the radial profile of this object to the J1414+5446 detection, the latter is clearly more extended (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>). For the star, 90 per cent of the total flux is contained within a 0<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${^{\\prime\\prime}_{.}}$|</span>15 radius, while for the LAE, this radius is 0<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${^{\\prime\\prime}_{.}}$|</span>45. The Ly\u00a0\u03b1 flux extends to 0<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${^{\\prime\\prime}_{.}}$|</span>6 in this relatively shallow image (the surface brightness limit is \u223c22.3 mag arcsec<sup>\u22122</sup>). Note that component B is separated from the LAE by \u223c0.4 arcsec and contributes a small amount of flux to the F850LP profile; however, it is undetected in the narrowband image. Several faint features appear to extend outwards from the central source after smoothing the narrowband image, although they are weak and do not permit a detailed morphological analysis.</p>                        <a id=\"118502115\" scrollto-destination=\"118502115\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig6\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/1/10.1093_mnras_sty1411/1/m_sty1411fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611465923&amp;Signature=Sl4Ov9pE6aKT0D9249SvVJEQ5eHePHu1q8~4MoRsYvNUMKy38SN8fRUjRr~jaG0846J2U6uqkbblTf7c09s5v9Hqikq23RSB9FbHu3LA-mqKdcpq4wQ4SuR63kx9xK~rzGig7-qZtZy8rZCp2shJbUD2D4uy9XQCEr-SmeRkrcLflUoUNYTzJW48TBY1jOJ2B5R1ujaxcixE91TaXocc7VYyKgZC0hOTv2HU1uspcSYADFcljjDpmb0WCzgg6EsuOgJurAXczZLqYLnQyTOGz4wACwufa0shILAYyFaWP~6uNJ0u~1YDex3574h20GeOYOqB8WOgq9lssC0158dCyQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Radial profiles of the Ly\u00a0\u03b1 (FR782N) and UV continuum (F850LP) emission, expressed as the average surface brightness of pixels within radial annuli of width 0${^{\\prime\\prime}_{.}}$03, normalized by the total flux in a 1.2-arcsec aperture. The profile from the PSF derived for the F850LP image is marked a light grey line, while the LAE profile is black. The profile from the single reference star in the narrowband image is shown in light blue, while the LAE profile is dark blue. Errors on the radial profiles are typically smaller than the line width and not displayed.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1411fig6.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/118502115/sty1411fig6.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1411fig6.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"118502115\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/1/10.1093_mnras_sty1411/1/sty1411fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611465923&Signature=sltnr3bw6qte-3ED9kzOp6vjAHyRaD5NhFiIrWxsP1~XspcEJhMMLOG8mXsMuhkxL~RzLjHibt0bkmMqtyg36flhwz9ERzTuOtSYn1CHL9OcIQ0WM~kp5-IVylPoUNBzb3WK3wTjLBiZ~OzOwWK8jqBGHCe4h0sNHCXy2QEOdZGMn8SJ9lKDf8oXjAQaqHDTIxL0paAajreGr95-2dSUwbLCgeui~vlF0Ml8Rizi62r8WFizup6WzZvMuOqa7uioSajuzaZswXYxDCaise863YDcrexoDnienBpDD7MgO1JrUdTpvsP11i1CuGJ95cupzpyqFjC~p2hlVCipSvhEpQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=118502115&ar=5026178&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1411fig6.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Radial profiles of the Ly\u00a0\u03b1 (FR782N) and UV continuum (F850LP) emission, expressed as the average surface brightness of pixels within radial annuli of width 0<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${^{\\prime\\prime}_{.}}$|</span>03, normalized by the total flux in a 1.2-arcsec aperture. The profile from the PSF derived for the F850LP image is marked a light grey line, while the LAE profile is black. The profile from the single reference star in the narrowband image is shown in light blue, while the LAE profile is dark blue. Errors on the radial profiles are typically smaller than the line width and not displayed.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig6\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/1/10.1093_mnras_sty1411/1/m_sty1411fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611465923&amp;Signature=Sl4Ov9pE6aKT0D9249SvVJEQ5eHePHu1q8~4MoRsYvNUMKy38SN8fRUjRr~jaG0846J2U6uqkbblTf7c09s5v9Hqikq23RSB9FbHu3LA-mqKdcpq4wQ4SuR63kx9xK~rzGig7-qZtZy8rZCp2shJbUD2D4uy9XQCEr-SmeRkrcLflUoUNYTzJW48TBY1jOJ2B5R1ujaxcixE91TaXocc7VYyKgZC0hOTv2HU1uspcSYADFcljjDpmb0WCzgg6EsuOgJurAXczZLqYLnQyTOGz4wACwufa0shILAYyFaWP~6uNJ0u~1YDex3574h20GeOYOqB8WOgq9lssC0158dCyQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Radial profiles of the Ly\u00a0\u03b1 (FR782N) and UV continuum (F850LP) emission, expressed as the average surface brightness of pixels within radial annuli of width 0${^{\\prime\\prime}_{.}}$03, normalized by the total flux in a 1.2-arcsec aperture. The profile from the PSF derived for the F850LP image is marked a light grey line, while the LAE profile is black. The profile from the single reference star in the narrowband image is shown in light blue, while the LAE profile is dark blue. Errors on the radial profiles are typically smaller than the line width and not displayed.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1411fig6.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/118502115/sty1411fig6.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1411fig6.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"118502115\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/1/10.1093_mnras_sty1411/1/sty1411fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611465923&Signature=sltnr3bw6qte-3ED9kzOp6vjAHyRaD5NhFiIrWxsP1~XspcEJhMMLOG8mXsMuhkxL~RzLjHibt0bkmMqtyg36flhwz9ERzTuOtSYn1CHL9OcIQ0WM~kp5-IVylPoUNBzb3WK3wTjLBiZ~OzOwWK8jqBGHCe4h0sNHCXy2QEOdZGMn8SJ9lKDf8oXjAQaqHDTIxL0paAajreGr95-2dSUwbLCgeui~vlF0Ml8Rizi62r8WFizup6WzZvMuOqa7uioSajuzaZswXYxDCaise863YDcrexoDnienBpDD7MgO1JrUdTpvsP11i1CuGJ95cupzpyqFjC~p2hlVCipSvhEpQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=118502115&ar=5026178&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1411fig6.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Radial profiles of the Ly\u00a0\u03b1 (FR782N) and UV continuum (F850LP) emission, expressed as the average surface brightness of pixels within radial annuli of width 0<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${^{\\prime\\prime}_{.}}$|</span>03, normalized by the total flux in a 1.2-arcsec aperture. The profile from the PSF derived for the F850LP image is marked a light grey line, while the LAE profile is black. The profile from the single reference star in the narrowband image is shown in light blue, while the LAE profile is dark blue. Errors on the radial profiles are typically smaller than the line width and not displayed.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">In general, the lack of (or very weak) extended Ly\u00a0\u03b1 emission is in contrast to some recent work that finds extended Ly\u00a0\u03b1 haloes around high-redshift galaxies with strong Ly\u00a0\u03b1 emission, with the line emission extending over a region 5\u201310\u00d7 greater than the continuum emission (e.g. Wisotzki et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib75\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib75\" data-open=\"bib75\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Smit et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib62\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib62\" data-open=\"bib62\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). J1414+5446 may lack the conditions required for such a halo to form. Alternatively, the central region may be in a region of higher lensing magnification compared to the more extended halo (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-5\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4.5</a> for discussion of the lensing properties).</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=118502117 id=\"118502117\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4>4 PHYSICAL PROPERTIES OF THE GALAXY</h2>\r\n                    <h3 scrollto-destination=118502118 id=\"118502118\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-1>4.1 Spatial extent</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">From the analysis of the <em>HST</em> imaging presented in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3</a>, we conclude that both the UV continuum and Ly\u00a0\u03b1 emission from J1414+5446 are at best marginally resolved. Both show slight excess emission out to \u223c0<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${^{\\prime\\prime}_{.}}$|</span>6 (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>); however, it is difficult to draw robust conclusions on any differences between the UV continuum and Ly\u00a0\u03b1 morphology from the available images.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=118502120 id=\"118502120\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-2>4.2 Rest frame UV spectra</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">J1414+5446 is exceptionally bright at optical wavelengths and provides a unique opportunity to probe the physical conditions in a high-redshift galaxy using typical diagnostic tools applied to rest frame UV spectra. The \u223c9-h LBT spectrum achieves an <em>S</em>/<em>N</em> of \u223c3 in the rest-UV continuum (\u223c1250 \u00c5) and can be used to explore key emission and absorption features at these wavelengths.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The foreground interloper complicates the interpretation of the LBT spectrum. Fortunately, the <em>HST</em> imaging constrains the expected UV continuum from the LAE such that we can roughly correct for the foreground contamination. This issue is evident at the stage of combining the spectra from the three different nights: two of the masks of the MODS masks (#505919 and #510122) were aligned at a PA of \u221214 deg, nearly orthogonal to the orientation between the foreground object and the LAE in the WFC3 images (see Fig. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>). The third mask (#523405) was aligned at PA = 50 deg, closer to parallel between the orientation of the two components. A greater degree of foreground contamination would be expected in this mask, and indeed, the EW of Ly\u00a0\u03b1 measured from this spectrum \u2013 using a direct fit to the observed continuum \u2013 is nearly half that measured from the other two spectra. We note that there is no evidence for spatially extended emission in the 2D spectra at the resolution of the LBT seeing (\u223c0.6\u20131.0 arcsec).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The full LBT/MODS1 spectrum is presented in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>, while a zoom on the Ly\u00a0\u03b1 feature in both the LBT and MMT/1200 gpm spectra can be seen in Fig. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a>. Results obtained from analysis of the spectra are given in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl4\" data-open=\"tbl4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"118502124\" scrollto-destination=\"118502124\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig7\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 7.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/1/10.1093_mnras_sty1411/1/m_sty1411fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611465923&amp;Signature=eS6vy5Ix68h3SjnK6JxzXgjojo-it4QHEw-LQfFVctkvl661IZuFhv-j1dNjhV1TQQ0nO5SIkuoLFBZTOJS2ypjNqv7UPGw1Y63SBKnX3QE4oqsJcg1TjjCicOz838Jd6AKmwCwCeM9JwRLLrSx~cF6e~fbQUHQZEtJHStiD7EJF0YzLl8J4K~MP4dKV6vUytEzu8A-44MmtX8M6sg1~28uAjslAlbHOEF1qUzSv0CnvDgLlKyYnnJKE7NJor3Nlpe39gdXsZ4Ml71MMmhAaN3xw5QspccNfVo8hyRg8YP3LdzLzbcGgnAdkF~3q0sJX0OhiJj0NyveDXE7kYsdAeQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Ly\u00a0\u03b1 emission profiles from the MMT/Red Channel 1200 gpm spectrum (left) and LBT/MODS (right). The upper panels display the 2D spectra over an extent of 8 arcsec for the MMT spectrum and 6 arcsec for the LBT spectrum (the LBT spectrum has been binned by a factor of 2 along the spatial axis for display purposes). In the lower panels, the orange-shaded regions span the \u00b11\u03c3 errors, and the green dashed lines mark the continuum level obtained from fitting the spectrum at \u223c8000 \u00c5. The blue line shows the result of the truncated Gaussian profile fit, convolved with the profile of each instrument. This profile fits the core of the line reasonably well but fails to account for the extended red wing of the line. The inset panel displays a zoom on the MODS spectrum, showing that the flux drops only to the continuum level at \u223c7870 \u00c5, corresponding to +2300\u2009 km \u2009s\u22121 from the peak of the Ly\u00a0\u03b1 emission. We compared the 2D profile of the high S/N MODS spectrum with reference stars included in the same slit mask and see no evidence for spatially extended Ly\u00a0\u03b1 emission at \u223c1 arcsec resolution.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1411fig7.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/118502124/sty1411fig7.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1411fig7.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"118502124\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/1/10.1093_mnras_sty1411/1/sty1411fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611465923&Signature=4ZrvCOUk6iChl0Ru4NxR~Qi8~PWGyjqtGOq4djJHvZDu6i145LGhDKBPHQNaFroU24vsWXHivoMgMGnypRGj3e2ny2haBc4SIzGMufXF77wka1ItaCypNj2xpr9lwAfGvhVFmPkkQqO7IKFaBvdf7AdzhgIw2fA1wZ24SsCfbdFG9m~xgWWfRbLBaLouACE1BM1rdzg8FQiWnemq04Hjr-6XMpiJ61pyAMPS8y4zwVXgOFtoXkCsIc0FhBBgERZsFsMUeq2npOJmLKKV9nYqTU-SrElM4TqsXwe61wV6Hjbbl5IyfwZfELod4DwFQ0CPMAz6bIrz9rbDrRefSNDwSg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=118502124&ar=5026178&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1411fig7.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Ly\u00a0\u03b1 emission profiles from the MMT/Red Channel 1200 gpm spectrum (left) and LBT/MODS (right). The upper panels display the 2D spectra over an extent of 8 arcsec for the MMT spectrum and 6 arcsec for the LBT spectrum (the LBT spectrum has been binned by a factor of 2 along the spatial axis for display purposes). In the lower panels, the orange-shaded regions span the \u00b11\u03c3 errors, and the green dashed lines mark the continuum level obtained from fitting the spectrum at \u223c8000 \u00c5. The blue line shows the result of the truncated Gaussian profile fit, convolved with the profile of each instrument. This profile fits the core of the line reasonably well but fails to account for the extended red wing of the line. The inset panel displays a zoom on the MODS spectrum, showing that the flux drops only to the continuum level at \u223c7870 \u00c5, corresponding to +2300\u2009 km \u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup> from the peak of the Ly\u00a0\u03b1 emission. We compared the 2D profile of the high <em>S</em>/<em>N</em> MODS spectrum with reference stars included in the same slit mask and see no evidence for spatially extended Ly\u00a0\u03b1 emission at \u223c1 arcsec resolution.</p></div></div>                        <a id=\"118502125\" scrollto-destination=\"118502125\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl4\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl4\" data-id=\"tbl4\"><span class=\"label\">Table 4.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Summary of physical quantities obtained from analysis of the LBT spectrum and <em>HST</em> imaging.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Property<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Value<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>R.A. class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th>Property<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Value<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: id=\"fn-tblf2\"></span><div content-id=\"tblf2\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Notes</em>. Rest frame EWs are given in units of \u00c5, line fluxes in erg s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u2009cm<sup>\u22122</sup>, continuum flux densities in erg s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u2009cm<sup>\u22122</sup>\u00c5<sup>\u22121</sup>, luminosities in erg s<sup>\u22121</sup>, and SFRs in M<sub>\u2299</sub>\u2009yr<sup>\u22121</sup>. Values indicated as being derived from photometry are obtained from the continuum fit to the resolved <em>HST</em> photometry. EW errors include a factor of 50 per cent uncertainty on the continuum level.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-tblf3\"></span><div content-id=\"tblf3\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em><sup>a</sup></em> No lensing correction has been applied to the luminosities or quantities derived from them.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/118502125\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl4\" data-id=\"tbl4\"><span class=\"label\">Table 4.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Summary of physical quantities obtained from analysis of the LBT spectrum and <em>HST</em> imaging.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Property<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Value<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>R.A. Rest frame EWs are given in units of \u00c5, line fluxes in erg s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u2009cm<sup>\u22122</sup>, continuum flux densities in erg s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u2009cm<sup>\u22122</sup>\u00c5<sup>\u22121</sup>, luminosities in erg s<sup>\u22121</sup>, and SFRs in M<sub>\u2299</sub>\u2009yr<sup>\u22121</sup>. Values indicated as being derived from photometry are obtained from the continuum fit to the resolved <em>HST</em> photometry. EW errors include a factor of 50 per cent uncertainty on the continuum level.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-tblf3\"></span><div content-id=\"tblf3\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em><sup>a</sup></em> No lensing correction has been applied to the luminosities or quantities derived from them.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/118502125\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                        <a id=\"118502126\" scrollto-destination=\"118502126\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl5\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl5\" data-id=\"tbl5\"><span class=\"label\">Table 5.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Photometry for the foreground galaxy from CFHT and <em>HST</em>.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Band<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span><sub>850</sub>\u00a0</td><td>24.43 \u00b1 0.17\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>H</em><sub>160</sub>\u00a0</td><td>23.70 \u00b1 0.02\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th>Band<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>AB mag<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td><em>u</em>\u00a0</td><td>26.45 \u00b1 0.28\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>g</em>\u00a0</td><td>26.58 \u00b1 0.23\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>V</em><sub>606</sub>\u00a0</td><td>25.30 \u00b1 0.10\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span><sub>850</sub>\u00a0</td><td>24.43 \u00b1 0.17\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>H</em><sub>160</sub>\u00a0</td><td>23.70 \u00b1 0.02\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/118502126\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl5\" data-id=\"tbl5\"><span class=\"label\">Table 5.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Photometry for the foreground galaxy from CFHT and <em>HST</em>.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Band<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>AB mag<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td><em>u</em>\u00a0</td><td>26.45 \u00b1 0.28\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>g</em>\u00a0</td><td>26.58 \u00b1 0.23\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>V</em><sub>606</sub>\u00a0</td><td>25.30 \u00b1 0.10\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span><sub>850</sub>\u00a0</td><td>24.43 \u00b1 0.17\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>H</em><sub>160</sub>\u00a0</td><td>23.70 \u00b1 0.02\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th>Band<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>AB mag<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td><em>u</em>\u00a0</td><td>26.45 \u00b1 0.28\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>g</em>\u00a0</td><td>26.58 \u00b1 0.23\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>V</em><sub>606</sub>\u00a0</td><td>25.30 \u00b1 0.10\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span><sub>850</sub>\u00a0</td><td>24.43 \u00b1 0.17\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>H</em><sub>160</sub>\u00a0</td><td>23.70 \u00b1 0.02\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/118502126\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sub>Ly\u00a0\u03b1</sub><em>Ly\u00a0\u03b1 emission:</em> We first examine the strong Ly\u00a0\u03b1 emission feature. We extract a line flux by integrating the spectrum between 7800 \u00c5 and 7850 \u00c5 after subtracting a fit to the continuum redward of the line at 8000 \u00c5. This observed flux \u2013 11.5 \u00d7 10<sup>\u221216</sup>erg s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u2009cm<sup>\u22122</sup> \u2013 is exceptionally large, even when compared to other lensed galaxies at high redshift. Ignoring gravitational lensing,<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn4\" data-open=\"fn4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">4</a></sup> this corresponds to a line luminosity of <em>L</em> \u223c 4 \u00d7 10<sup>44</sup> erg s<sup>\u22121</sup>. We obtain a raw EW<sub>0</sub>(Ly\u00a0\u03b1) = 214 \u00b1 5 \u00c5 using the continuum fit. We estimate the contaminating flux of the foreground object to the continuum using the <em>HST</em> photometry; after removing this flux, we obtain a corrected value of EW<sub>0</sub>(Ly\u00a0\u03b1) \u223c260\u00c5, in excellent agreement with the results from the <em>HST</em> narrowband image (Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.3</a>). We also derive a simple non-parametric estimate for the linewidth by measuring the red Half-Width at Half-Maximum (rHWHM; the width of the red side of the line profile at half of the peak value). Using the higher resolution MMT/1200-gpm spectrum and correcting for the instrumental profile (FWHM \u223c100 km s<sup>\u22121</sup>), the measured rHWHM is 160 km s<sup>\u22121</sup>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">It can be seen from Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a> that the Ly\u00a0\u03b1 emission extends to &gt;2000 km s<sup>\u22121</sup> redward of the peak. This can be compared to a <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span> = 5.7 LAE reported by Yang et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib78\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib78\" data-open=\"bib78\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) to have a red wing extending &gt;1000 km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup> from the peak of the Ly\u00a0\u03b1 emission and similar \u2018shoulders\u2019 observed in the red wings of bright, high-redshift LAEs (e.g. Lidman et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib39\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib39\" data-open=\"bib39\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Smit et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib62\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib62\" data-open=\"bib62\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). As with these examples, J1414+5446 is sufficiently bright \u2013 both in the continuum and line emission \u2013 to permit detailed studies of the line profile.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The observed features of the Ly\u00a0\u03b1 spectrum can be attributed to scattering through an outflow, which is usually represented as an expanding, dusty shell of neutral hydrogen (Verhamme et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib72\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib72\" data-open=\"bib72\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; Gronke et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib25\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib25\" data-open=\"bib25\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). We apply the automated fitting routine described in Gronke et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib25\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib25\" data-open=\"bib25\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) to find the best-fitting shell model for the observed Ly\u00a0\u03b1 profile. Briefly, this method fits a model with six shell model parameters to the observed spectrum: expansion velocity (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$v$|</span><sub>exp</sub>), hydrogen column density (<em>N</em><sub>HI</sub>), effective temperature (<em>T</em>), intrinsic dispersion of the Ly\u00a0\u03b1 line (\u03c3<sub>i</sub>), dust optical depth (\u03c4<sub>d</sub>), and the intrinsic equivalent width of the line (EW<sub>i</sub>). In addition, the systemic redshift (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$z$|\u2060</span>) is included in the fit. The best fit is determined through a \u03c7<sup>2</sup> minimization and the likelihood surfaces are characterized with a Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) approach. Further details of the fitting technique, including the parameter space explored by the simulations, may be found in Gronke et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib25\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib25\" data-open=\"bib25\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sub>Ly\u00a0\u03b1</sub><sub>Ly\u00a0\u03b1</sub>Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig8\" data-open=\"fig8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">8</a> presents the results of the shell model fits. The <em>solid red line</em> represents the best-fitting model obtained after imposing a narrow Gaussian prior with \u03c3<sub><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$v$|</span></sub> = 15 km s<sup>\u22121</sup> and centred at <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span> = 5.4237. These values were selected based on the results of fitting the N\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span>] line, which we assume to be at the systemic redshift. The data require (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$v$|</span><sub>exp</sub>, log\u2009<em>N</em><sub>HI</sub>) \u223c (350 km s<sup>\u22121</sup>, 19.5). The observed Ly\u00a0\u03b1 line shift of \u0394<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$v$|</span> \u223c70 km s<sup>\u22121</sup> primarily sets the constraint on <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$v$|</span><sub>exp</sub>. The intrinsic width of the Ly\u00a0\u03b1 line is found to be FWHM<sub>int</sub> \u223c 250 km s<sup>\u22121</sup>. The latter is in remarkably good agreement with the width inferred from the N\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span> line (see below). What is surprising is that the best-fitting model favours the shell to be dusty, with \u03c4<sub>d</sub> \u223c2. This translates to Ly\u00a0\u03b1 escape fractions of <em>f</em><sub>esc</sub> \u223c10 per cent. Given the large EW of the Ly\u00a0\u03b1 emission from this galaxy, this low Ly\u00a0\u03b1 escape fraction is not likely to be physical. The <em>solid blue line</em> shows the best-fitting model, if we force a lower \u03c4<sub>d</sub> through a strong prior and also fix the redshift at <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span> = 5.24. The data still favour dusty solutions with \u03c4<sub>d</sub> \u223c1.0 (the other model parameters are barely affected), leading to an Ly\u00a0\u03b1 escape fraction of <em>f</em><sub>esc</sub> \u223c30 per cent. This is still low but at least consistent with inferred Ly\u00a0\u03b1 escape fractions for galaxies that have similar \u0394<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$v$|</span> (e.g. Erb et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Yang et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib79\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib79\" data-open=\"bib79\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). It is not possible to find shell model solutions with lower \u03c4<sub>d</sub>: the observed velocity shift of the Ly\u00a0\u03b1 line constrains the parameters (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$v$|</span><sub>exp</sub>, log\u2009<em>N</em><sub>HI</sub>). Generally, Ly\u00a0\u03b1 scattering broadens spectral lines in the absence of dust. In the presence of dust, scattering and spectral broadening are limited. The observed narrowness of the Ly\u00a0\u03b1 spectral line (and the absence of a blue peak) then requires at least some dust. Another possibility to be considered at this high redshift is the impact of the IGM that also narrows the observed Ly\u00a0\u03b1 line and extinguishes the blue peak (Dijkstra, Lidz &amp; Wyithe <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>), thus, mimicking the effect of dust (as discussed in Gronke <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>).</p>                        <a id=\"118502131\" scrollto-destination=\"118502131\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig8\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 8.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/1/10.1093_mnras_sty1411/1/m_sty1411fig8.jpeg?Expires=1611465923&amp;Signature=g9o3pnuEQbbWoKWn7qV0gKbNX5SALdqYsNLlY33nP49fChAlmoWUF1xTjADWMCbGv35hZyCJ2eOiYPRJIpET0Qrsy7bBNqZW1kYgoykxY7uIyWpJeHq8i5VgdFoVCSadRHJHqTWajn7D-UcWAlcWLAR80mPRrO3-WyS6psFIehjesLeXnPk5n8VQHtIz5hgznOGiJFBO3JYsi6AIaOwACQKAyg-Qjd7Chr71NByxqo~B0PLuOn-8zuHurt2mBe6zv-8bI0NeWExx78jA-mdhwJFj1HMX2exAuyPxxBbJ3R-PZHq3KFQNuHC89oS65I2r5JdCNodYyeeiGa3Ek70T6w__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Results of shell model fits to the Ly\u00a0\u03b1 line using the automated procedure from Gronke et\u00a0al. (2015). The black line shows the observed spectrum, with horizontal error bars overlaid. The dashed lines show the intrinsic Ly\u00a0\u03b1 profiles from the model fits; the model with a large \u03c4d is shown in red and the model with a strong dust prior is shown in blue. The solid lines show the resulting profile after including radiative transfer through the expanding shell. Parameter values for the fit with large \u03c4d are given on the left and for the constrained \u03c4d on the right.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1411fig8.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/118502131/sty1411fig8.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1411fig8.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"118502131\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/1/10.1093_mnras_sty1411/1/sty1411fig8.jpeg?Expires=1611465923&Signature=J~qLIbeaIdY2u10Dygd~dtoy~i8mD0cKlUJtdkykG1jGmI0KIalRFMC-Dbog1l26v8ZbkAx6I37YrCd~dyMkpbogAvY4k4JbE2OWZZC4hppRS5yQh3Wd2RYAA2KhYD8MzhRL5BWC14tW1SW~PY36LcV3dSrC44ILvPetoMzuekFSmyf02vBcPvo5JOlQISrHLt0hoob~CbyWv2jpUdogUtQBqT1nTSS7AguSO90IQZeE9o7JtmpHE2YxMFcP9OT~zeulfZ1TKm~Iu45TSDf71f1NIklPDONxoxQYFGlI0GZGE4keK7pJi0-3EMhezxyr6OzyjGsKaKWtDz03sufw9g__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=118502131&ar=5026178&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1411fig8.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Results of shell model fits to the Ly\u00a0\u03b1 line using the automated procedure from Gronke et\u00a0al. The black line shows the observed spectrum, with horizontal error bars overlaid. The dashed lines show the intrinsic Ly\u00a0\u03b1 profiles from the model fits; the model with a large \u03c4<sub>d</sub> is shown in red and the model with a strong dust prior is shown in blue. The solid lines show the resulting profile after including radiative transfer through the expanding shell. Parameter values for the fit with large \u03c4<sub>d</sub> are given on the left and for the constrained \u03c4<sub>d</sub> on the right.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig8\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 8.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/1/10.1093_mnras_sty1411/1/m_sty1411fig8.jpeg?Expires=1611465923&amp;Signature=g9o3pnuEQbbWoKWn7qV0gKbNX5SALdqYsNLlY33nP49fChAlmoWUF1xTjADWMCbGv35hZyCJ2eOiYPRJIpET0Qrsy7bBNqZW1kYgoykxY7uIyWpJeHq8i5VgdFoVCSadRHJHqTWajn7D-UcWAlcWLAR80mPRrO3-WyS6psFIehjesLeXnPk5n8VQHtIz5hgznOGiJFBO3JYsi6AIaOwACQKAyg-Qjd7Chr71NByxqo~B0PLuOn-8zuHurt2mBe6zv-8bI0NeWExx78jA-mdhwJFj1HMX2exAuyPxxBbJ3R-PZHq3KFQNuHC89oS65I2r5JdCNodYyeeiGa3Ek70T6w__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Results of shell model fits to the Ly\u00a0\u03b1 line using the automated procedure from Gronke et\u00a0al. (2015). The black line shows the observed spectrum, with horizontal error bars overlaid.
