The upper panels display the 2D spectra over an extent of 8 arcsec for the MMT spectrum and 6 arcsec for the LBT spectrum (the LBT spectrum has been binned by a factor of 2 along the spatial axis for display purposes). In the lower panels, the orange-shaded regions span the \u00b11\u03c3 errors, and the green dashed lines mark the continuum level obtained from fitting the spectrum at \u223c8000 \u00c5. The blue line shows the result of the truncated Gaussian profile fit, convolved with the profile of each instrument. This profile fits the core of the line reasonably well but fails to account for the extended red wing of the line. The inset panel displays a zoom on the MODS spectrum, showing that the flux drops only to the continuum level at \u223c7870 \u00c5, corresponding to +2300\u2009 km \u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup> from the peak of the Ly\u00a0\u03b1 emission. We compared the 2D profile of the high <em>S</em>/<em>N</em> MODS spectrum with reference stars included in the same slit mask and see no evidence for spatially extended Ly\u00a0\u03b1 emission at \u223c1 arcsec resolution.</p></div></div>                        <a id=\"118502125\" scrollto-destination=\"118502125\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl4\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl4\" data-id=\"tbl4\"><span class=\"label\">Table 4.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Summary of physical quantities obtained from analysis of the LBT spectrum and <em>HST</em> imaging.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Property<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Value<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>R.A. class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th>Property<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Value<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: id=\"fn-tblf2\"></span><div content-id=\"tblf2\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Notes</em>. Rest frame EWs are given in units of \u00c5, line fluxes in erg s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u2009cm<sup>\u22122</sup>, continuum flux densities in erg s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u2009cm<sup>\u22122</sup>\u00c5<sup>\u22121</sup>, luminosities in erg s<sup>\u22121</sup>, and SFRs in M<sub>\u2299</sub>\u2009yr<sup>\u22121</sup>. Values indicated as being derived from photometry are obtained from the continuum fit to the resolved <em>HST</em> photometry. EW errors include a factor of 50 per cent uncertainty on the continuum level.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-tblf3\"></span><div content-id=\"tblf3\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em><sup>a</sup></em> No lensing correction has been applied to the luminosities or quantities derived from them.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/118502125\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl4\" data-id=\"tbl4\"><span class=\"label\">Table 4.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Summary of physical quantities obtained from analysis of the LBT spectrum and <em>HST</em> imaging.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Property<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Value<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>R.A. Rest frame EWs are given in units of \u00c5, line fluxes in erg s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u2009cm<sup>\u22122</sup>, continuum flux densities in erg s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u2009cm<sup>\u22122</sup>\u00c5<sup>\u22121</sup>, luminosities in erg s<sup>\u22121</sup>, and SFRs in M<sub>\u2299</sub>\u2009yr<sup>\u22121</sup>. Values indicated as being derived from photometry are obtained from the continuum fit to the resolved <em>HST</em> photometry. EW errors include a factor of 50 per cent uncertainty on the continuum level.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-tblf3\"></span><div content-id=\"tblf3\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em><sup>a</sup></em> No lensing correction has been applied to the luminosities or quantities derived from them.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/118502125\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                        <a id=\"118502126\" scrollto-destination=\"118502126\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl5\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl5\" data-id=\"tbl5\"><span class=\"label\">Table 5.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Photometry for the foreground galaxy from CFHT and <em>HST</em>.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Band<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span><sub>850</sub>\u00a0</td><td>24.43 \u00b1 0.17\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>H</em><sub>160</sub>\u00a0</td><td>23.70 \u00b1 0.02\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th>Band<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>AB mag<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td><em>u</em>\u00a0</td><td>26.45 \u00b1 0.28\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>g</em>\u00a0</td><td>26.58 \u00b1 0.23\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>V</em><sub>606</sub>\u00a0</td><td>25.30 \u00b1 0.10\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span><sub>850</sub>\u00a0</td><td>24.43 \u00b1 0.17\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>H</em><sub>160</sub>\u00a0</td><td>23.70 \u00b1 0.02\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/118502126\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl5\" data-id=\"tbl5\"><span class=\"label\">Table 5.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Photometry for the foreground galaxy from CFHT and <em>HST</em>.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Band<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>AB mag<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td><em>u</em>\u00a0</td><td>26.45 \u00b1 0.28\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>g</em>\u00a0</td><td>26.58 \u00b1 0.23\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>V</em><sub>606</sub>\u00a0</td><td>25.30 \u00b1 0.10\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span><sub>850</sub>\u00a0</td><td>24.43 \u00b1 0.17\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>H</em><sub>160</sub>\u00a0</td><td>23.70 \u00b1 0.02\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th>Band<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>AB mag<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td><em>u</em>\u00a0</td><td>26.45 \u00b1 0.28\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>g</em>\u00a0</td><td>26.58 \u00b1 0.23\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>V</em><sub>606</sub>\u00a0</td><td>25.30 \u00b1 0.10\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span><sub>850</sub>\u00a0</td><td>24.43 \u00b1 0.17\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>H</em><sub>160</sub>\u00a0</td><td>23.70 \u00b1 0.02\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/118502126\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sub>Ly\u00a0\u03b1</sub><em>Ly\u00a0\u03b1 emission:</em> We first examine the strong Ly\u00a0\u03b1 emission feature. We extract a line flux by integrating the spectrum between 7800 \u00c5 and 7850 \u00c5 after subtracting a fit to the continuum redward of the line at 8000 \u00c5. This observed flux \u2013 11.5 \u00d7 10<sup>\u221216</sup>erg s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u2009cm<sup>\u22122</sup> \u2013 is exceptionally large, even when compared to other lensed galaxies at high redshift. Ignoring gravitational lensing,<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn4\" data-open=\"fn4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">4</a></sup> this corresponds to a line luminosity of <em>L</em> \u223c 4 \u00d7 10<sup>44</sup> erg s<sup>\u22121</sup>. We obtain a raw EW<sub>0</sub>(Ly\u00a0\u03b1) = 214 \u00b1 5 \u00c5 using the continuum fit. We estimate the contaminating flux of the foreground object to the continuum using the <em>HST</em> photometry; after removing this flux, we obtain a corrected value of EW<sub>0</sub>(Ly\u00a0\u03b1) \u223c260\u00c5, in excellent agreement with the results from the <em>HST</em> narrowband image (Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.3</a>). We also derive a simple non-parametric estimate for the linewidth by measuring the red Half-Width at Half-Maximum (rHWHM; the width of the red side of the line profile at half of the peak value). Using the higher resolution MMT/1200-gpm spectrum and correcting for the instrumental profile (FWHM \u223c100 km s<sup>\u22121</sup>), the measured rHWHM is 160 km s<sup>\u22121</sup>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">It can be seen from Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a> that the Ly\u00a0\u03b1 emission extends to &gt;2000 km s<sup>\u22121</sup> redward of the peak. This can be compared to a <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span> = 5.7 LAE reported by Yang et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib78\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib78\" data-open=\"bib78\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) to have a red wing extending &gt;1000 km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup> from the peak of the Ly\u00a0\u03b1 emission and similar \u2018shoulders\u2019 observed in the red wings of bright, high-redshift LAEs (e.g. Lidman et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib39\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib39\" data-open=\"bib39\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Smit et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib62\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib62\" data-open=\"bib62\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). As with these examples, J1414+5446 is sufficiently bright \u2013 both in the continuum and line emission \u2013 to permit detailed studies of the line profile.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The observed features of the Ly\u00a0\u03b1 spectrum can be attributed to scattering through an outflow, which is usually represented as an expanding, dusty shell of neutral hydrogen (Verhamme et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib72\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib72\" data-open=\"bib72\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; Gronke et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib25\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib25\" data-open=\"bib25\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). We apply the automated fitting routine described in Gronke et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib25\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib25\" data-open=\"bib25\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) to find the best-fitting shell model for the observed Ly\u00a0\u03b1 profile. Briefly, this method fits a model with six shell model parameters to the observed spectrum: expansion velocity (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$v$|</span><sub>exp</sub>), hydrogen column density (<em>N</em><sub>HI</sub>), effective temperature (<em>T</em>), intrinsic dispersion of the Ly\u00a0\u03b1 line (\u03c3<sub>i</sub>), dust optical depth (\u03c4<sub>d</sub>), and the intrinsic equivalent width of the line (EW<sub>i</sub>). In addition, the systemic redshift (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$z$|\u2060</span>) is included in the fit. The best fit is determined through a \u03c7<sup>2</sup> minimization and the likelihood surfaces are characterized with a Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) approach. Further details of the fitting technique, including the parameter space explored by the simulations, may be found in Gronke et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib25\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib25\" data-open=\"bib25\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sub>Ly\u00a0\u03b1</sub><sub>Ly\u00a0\u03b1</sub>Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig8\" data-open=\"fig8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">8</a> presents the results of the shell model fits. The <em>solid red line</em> represents the best-fitting model obtained after imposing a narrow Gaussian prior with \u03c3<sub><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$v$|</span></sub> = 15 km s<sup>\u22121</sup> and centred at <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span> = 5.4237. These values were selected based on the results of fitting the N\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span>] line, which we assume to be at the systemic redshift. The data require (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$v$|</span><sub>exp</sub>, log\u2009<em>N</em><sub>HI</sub>) \u223c (350 km s<sup>\u22121</sup>, 19.5). The observed Ly\u00a0\u03b1 line shift of \u0394<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$v$|</span> \u223c70 km s<sup>\u22121</sup> primarily sets the constraint on <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$v$|</span><sub>exp</sub>. The intrinsic width of the Ly\u00a0\u03b1 line is found to be FWHM<sub>int</sub> \u223c 250 km s<sup>\u22121</sup>. The latter is in remarkably good agreement with the width inferred from the N\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span> line (see below). What is surprising is that the best-fitting model favours the shell to be dusty, with \u03c4<sub>d</sub> \u223c2. This translates to Ly\u00a0\u03b1 escape fractions of <em>f</em><sub>esc</sub> \u223c10 per cent. Given the large EW of the Ly\u00a0\u03b1 emission from this galaxy, this low Ly\u00a0\u03b1 escape fraction is not likely to be physical. The <em>solid blue line</em> shows the best-fitting model, if we force a lower \u03c4<sub>d</sub> through a strong prior and also fix the redshift at <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span> = 5.24. The data still favour dusty solutions with \u03c4<sub>d</sub> \u223c1.0 (the other model parameters are barely affected), leading to an Ly\u00a0\u03b1 escape fraction of <em>f</em><sub>esc</sub> \u223c30 per cent. This is still low but at least consistent with inferred Ly\u00a0\u03b1 escape fractions for galaxies that have similar \u0394<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$v$|</span> (e.g. Erb et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Yang et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib79\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib79\" data-open=\"bib79\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). It is not possible to find shell model solutions with lower \u03c4<sub>d</sub>: the observed velocity shift of the Ly\u00a0\u03b1 line constrains the parameters (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$v$|</span><sub>exp</sub>, log\u2009<em>N</em><sub>HI</sub>). Generally, Ly\u00a0\u03b1 scattering broadens spectral lines in the absence of dust. In the presence of dust, scattering and spectral broadening are limited. The observed narrowness of the Ly\u00a0\u03b1 spectral line (and the absence of a blue peak) then requires at least some dust. Another possibility to be considered at this high redshift is the impact of the IGM that also narrows the observed Ly\u00a0\u03b1 line and extinguishes the blue peak (Dijkstra, Lidz &amp; Wyithe <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>), thus, mimicking the effect of dust (as discussed in Gronke <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>).</p>                        <a id=\"118502131\" scrollto-destination=\"118502131\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig8\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 8.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/1/10.1093_mnras_sty1411/1/m_sty1411fig8.jpeg?Expires=1611465923&amp;Signature=g9o3pnuEQbbWoKWn7qV0gKbNX5SALdqYsNLlY33nP49fChAlmoWUF1xTjADWMCbGv35hZyCJ2eOiYPRJIpET0Qrsy7bBNqZW1kYgoykxY7uIyWpJeHq8i5VgdFoVCSadRHJHqTWajn7D-UcWAlcWLAR80mPRrO3-WyS6psFIehjesLeXnPk5n8VQHtIz5hgznOGiJFBO3JYsi6AIaOwACQKAyg-Qjd7Chr71NByxqo~B0PLuOn-8zuHurt2mBe6zv-8bI0NeWExx78jA-mdhwJFj1HMX2exAuyPxxBbJ3R-PZHq3KFQNuHC89oS65I2r5JdCNodYyeeiGa3Ek70T6w__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Results of shell model fits to the Ly\u00a0\u03b1 line using the automated procedure from Gronke et\u00a0al. (2015). The black line shows the observed spectrum, with horizontal error bars overlaid. The dashed lines show the intrinsic Ly\u00a0\u03b1 profiles from the model fits; the model with a large \u03c4d is shown in red and the model with a strong dust prior is shown in blue. The solid lines show the resulting profile after including radiative transfer through the expanding shell. Parameter values for the fit with large \u03c4d are given on the left and for the constrained \u03c4d on the right.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1411fig8.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/118502131/sty1411fig8.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1411fig8.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"118502131\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/1/10.1093_mnras_sty1411/1/sty1411fig8.jpeg?Expires=1611465923&Signature=J~qLIbeaIdY2u10Dygd~dtoy~i8mD0cKlUJtdkykG1jGmI0KIalRFMC-Dbog1l26v8ZbkAx6I37YrCd~dyMkpbogAvY4k4JbE2OWZZC4hppRS5yQh3Wd2RYAA2KhYD8MzhRL5BWC14tW1SW~PY36LcV3dSrC44ILvPetoMzuekFSmyf02vBcPvo5JOlQISrHLt0hoob~CbyWv2jpUdogUtQBqT1nTSS7AguSO90IQZeE9o7JtmpHE2YxMFcP9OT~zeulfZ1TKm~Iu45TSDf71f1NIklPDONxoxQYFGlI0GZGE4keK7pJi0-3EMhezxyr6OzyjGsKaKWtDz03sufw9g__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=118502131&ar=5026178&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1411fig8.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Results of shell model fits to the Ly\u00a0\u03b1 line using the automated procedure from Gronke et\u00a0al. The black line shows the observed spectrum, with horizontal error bars overlaid. The dashed lines show the intrinsic Ly\u00a0\u03b1 profiles from the model fits; the model with a large \u03c4<sub>d</sub> is shown in red and the model with a strong dust prior is shown in blue. The solid lines show the resulting profile after including radiative transfer through the expanding shell. Parameter values for the fit with large \u03c4<sub>d</sub> are given on the left and for the constrained \u03c4<sub>d</sub> on the right.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig8\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 8.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/1/10.1093_mnras_sty1411/1/m_sty1411fig8.jpeg?Expires=1611465923&amp;Signature=g9o3pnuEQbbWoKWn7qV0gKbNX5SALdqYsNLlY33nP49fChAlmoWUF1xTjADWMCbGv35hZyCJ2eOiYPRJIpET0Qrsy7bBNqZW1kYgoykxY7uIyWpJeHq8i5VgdFoVCSadRHJHqTWajn7D-UcWAlcWLAR80mPRrO3-WyS6psFIehjesLeXnPk5n8VQHtIz5hgznOGiJFBO3JYsi6AIaOwACQKAyg-Qjd7Chr71NByxqo~B0PLuOn-8zuHurt2mBe6zv-8bI0NeWExx78jA-mdhwJFj1HMX2exAuyPxxBbJ3R-PZHq3KFQNuHC89oS65I2r5JdCNodYyeeiGa3Ek70T6w__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Results of shell model fits to the Ly\u00a0\u03b1 line using the automated procedure from Gronke et\u00a0al. (2015). The black line shows the observed spectrum, with horizontal error bars overlaid.
