The solid lines show the resulting profile after including radiative transfer through the expanding shell. Parameter values for the fit with large \u03c4d are given on the left and for the constrained \u03c4d on the right.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1411fig8.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/118502131/sty1411fig8.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1411fig8.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"118502131\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/1/10.1093_mnras_sty1411/1/sty1411fig8.jpeg?Expires=1611465923&Signature=J~qLIbeaIdY2u10Dygd~dtoy~i8mD0cKlUJtdkykG1jGmI0KIalRFMC-Dbog1l26v8ZbkAx6I37YrCd~dyMkpbogAvY4k4JbE2OWZZC4hppRS5yQh3Wd2RYAA2KhYD8MzhRL5BWC14tW1SW~PY36LcV3dSrC44ILvPetoMzuekFSmyf02vBcPvo5JOlQISrHLt0hoob~CbyWv2jpUdogUtQBqT1nTSS7AguSO90IQZeE9o7JtmpHE2YxMFcP9OT~zeulfZ1TKm~Iu45TSDf71f1NIklPDONxoxQYFGlI0GZGE4keK7pJi0-3EMhezxyr6OzyjGsKaKWtDz03sufw9g__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=118502131&ar=5026178&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1411fig8.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Results of shell model fits to the Ly\u00a0\u03b1 line using the automated procedure from Gronke et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib25\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib25\" data-open=\"bib25\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). The black line shows the observed spectrum, with horizontal error bars overlaid. The dashed lines show the intrinsic Ly\u00a0\u03b1 profiles from the model fits; the model with a large \u03c4<sub>d</sub> is shown in red and the model with a strong dust prior is shown in blue. The solid lines show the resulting profile after including radiative transfer through the expanding shell. Parameter values for the fit with large \u03c4<sub>d</sub> are given on the left and for the constrained \u03c4<sub>d</sub> on the right.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The simple shell model has difficulty reproducing both the observed shift of the line (\u0394<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$v$|</span> \u223c70 \u2009km s<sup>\u22121</sup>) and the very extended red wing. With a narrow prior on redshift, the model fails to reproduce the observations at \u03bb &gt; 7825 \u00c5 (corresponding to \u0394<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$v$|</span> &gt; 500 \u2009km s<sup>\u22121</sup>). If a wide redshift prior is employed, the model is able to reproduce the extended red wing but underpredicts the overall shift of the line. This likely represents a shortcoming of the shell model. This tension could be alleviated by introducing a velocity gradient in the shell that would tend to \u2018smear out\u2019 the observed spectrum (e.g. Loeb &amp; Rybicki <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib40\" data-open=\"bib40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1999</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>N\u2009</em><span class=\"small-caps\">v</span><em>emission:</em> There is no N\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">v</span> \u03bb1240 emission as would be expected from an Active Galactic Nucleus (AGN). The continuum is detected at \u223c4 \u03c3pix<sup>\u22121</sup> in the region where N\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">v</span> would be located (and has relatively little foreground contamination); combined with the extremely large flux of the Ly\u00a0\u03b1 line, we obtain a stringent constraint of <em>f</em>(N\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">v</span>)/<em>f</em>(Ly\u00a0\u03b1) &lt;10<sup>\u22123</sup>(1\u03c3), compared to \u223c10 per cent for narrow-line AGN (Alexandroff et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1\" data-open=\"bib1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>N\u2009</em><span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span><em>] emission:</em> The only other clear detection of an emission line in the LBT spectrum is at 9549 \u00c5. We identify this line as N\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span>] 1486.5. While this emission line is rarely observed, it has been found in a galaxy with very similar properties to the one presented here. GDS J033218.92-275302.7 at <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span> = 5.56 has EW(N\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span>] 1486.5) \u224830 \u00c5 (Vanzella et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib70\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib70\" data-open=\"bib70\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>). This emission feature is a doublet, but in both cases no emission corresponding to N\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span>] 1483.3 is detected (we obtain a limit of <em>f</em>(N\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span>] 1483) &lt;1 \u00d7 10<sup>\u221217</sup>erg s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u2009cm<sup>\u22122</sup>). The width of the line is FWHM = 260 \u00b1 40 km s<sup>\u22121</sup> after correcting for instrumental resolution. The N\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span>] emission feature is displayed in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig9\" data-open=\"fig9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">9</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"118502135\" scrollto-destination=\"118502135\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig9\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 9.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/1/10.1093_mnras_sty1411/1/m_sty1411fig9.jpeg?Expires=1611465923&amp;Signature=biYQNAmnaHNyOjt40YEKxlmdamXjwyqwTFieBUQdq3nTxYzooYqvSHvZDnd3ejyarj~35dvoSysVzL0-UGYCJXsthBwGmJ7Ym72qFWjWrg2Ysmm8Vi5SyfeIS3CsocWRGN3zpDHf4GRPKnUtOFV4Gy-gVS1jW8ljAdgAMElav7TW6GVYANYPjLk0VwrzanrGTv9WkOjBUxArWRYBd6qUttujjfFtMidL0NN4yfF71RW-g5SszfWJGl23QgrjivaNATkRwUnagqyotfTt1YX77-BlXGMlrVvIwAkp6ucm~DJX36Mt72xa68v5CFOXz8vZG4ZI1StRkQDvotT0OilUdA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Zoom on the LBT spectrum at the wavelengths of the N\u2009iv] and C\u2009iv emission lines. The spectral flux density is represented by the solid lines and the \u00b11\u03c3 noise level by the orange-shaded region. The continuum level is denoted with a red dashed line. The blue vertical lines mark the expected locations of the doublet features for both lines using the redshift obtained from the peak of the Ly\u00a0\u03b1 line.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1411fig9.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/118502135/sty1411fig9.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1411fig9.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"118502135\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/1/10.1093_mnras_sty1411/1/sty1411fig9.jpeg?Expires=1611465923&Signature=eV3DwnsS~Ac~6x5BES84IPmHIhT0f28wLl9jyqeUHY58iew~07pvjl8RXpNPFthyhrCktccxjBViBg6t2EJgtPl01Sw1q3lUh4~XVVXjeoSFUkO-HQC6nwKxkh4uJL7qE-xeYC~YBZs1t8ETuNebqn7MLF339ub-inNsov10xCgKd7w1mYY6Tzmh6i65KGWiJiHAqaLyHUznGnJ287IXffGwarwSQx5K-rCl11NQTwmg0c-IdWqQ9L80XTPDCh5Srpo1oZEAVXMHWRbZLmOt5~4Kw2tUzL2icLVVPNvAYnhXIPvmglGLUV0J~tm5lL~wx57R3CWIwpPXBOL4HqZD~w__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=118502135&ar=5026178&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1411fig9.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Zoom on the LBT spectrum at the wavelengths of the N\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span>] and C\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span> emission lines. The spectral flux density is represented by the solid lines and the \u00b11\u03c3 noise level by the orange-shaded region. The continuum level is denoted with a red dashed line. The blue vertical lines mark the expected locations of the doublet features for both lines using the redshift obtained from the peak of the Ly\u00a0\u03b1 line.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig9\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 9.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/1/10.1093_mnras_sty1411/1/m_sty1411fig9.jpeg?Expires=1611465923&amp;Signature=biYQNAmnaHNyOjt40YEKxlmdamXjwyqwTFieBUQdq3nTxYzooYqvSHvZDnd3ejyarj~35dvoSysVzL0-UGYCJXsthBwGmJ7Ym72qFWjWrg2Ysmm8Vi5SyfeIS3CsocWRGN3zpDHf4GRPKnUtOFV4Gy-gVS1jW8ljAdgAMElav7TW6GVYANYPjLk0VwrzanrGTv9WkOjBUxArWRYBd6qUttujjfFtMidL0NN4yfF71RW-g5SszfWJGl23QgrjivaNATkRwUnagqyotfTt1YX77-BlXGMlrVvIwAkp6ucm~DJX36Mt72xa68v5CFOXz8vZG4ZI1StRkQDvotT0OilUdA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Zoom on the LBT spectrum at the wavelengths of the N\u2009iv] and C\u2009iv emission lines. The spectral flux density is represented by the solid lines and the \u00b11\u03c3 noise level by the orange-shaded region. The continuum level is denoted with a red dashed line. The blue vertical lines mark the expected locations of the doublet features for both lines using the redshift obtained from the peak of the Ly\u00a0\u03b1 line.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1411fig9.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/118502135/sty1411fig9.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1411fig9.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"118502135\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/1/10.1093_mnras_sty1411/1/sty1411fig9.jpeg?Expires=1611465923&Signature=eV3DwnsS~Ac~6x5BES84IPmHIhT0f28wLl9jyqeUHY58iew~07pvjl8RXpNPFthyhrCktccxjBViBg6t2EJgtPl01Sw1q3lUh4~XVVXjeoSFUkO-HQC6nwKxkh4uJL7qE-xeYC~YBZs1t8ETuNebqn7MLF339ub-inNsov10xCgKd7w1mYY6Tzmh6i65KGWiJiHAqaLyHUznGnJ287IXffGwarwSQx5K-rCl11NQTwmg0c-IdWqQ9L80XTPDCh5Srpo1oZEAVXMHWRbZLmOt5~4Kw2tUzL2icLVVPNvAYnhXIPvmglGLUV0J~tm5lL~wx57R3CWIwpPXBOL4HqZD~w__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=118502135&ar=5026178&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1411fig9.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Zoom on the LBT spectrum at the wavelengths of the N\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span>] and C\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span> emission lines. The spectral flux density is represented by the solid lines and the \u00b11\u03c3 noise level by the orange-shaded region. The continuum level is denoted with a red dashed line. The blue vertical lines mark the expected locations of the doublet features for both lines using the redshift obtained from the peak of the Ly\u00a0\u03b1 line.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>C\u2009 <span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span> emission:</em> The expected wavelength of C\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span> \u03bb1550 is at 9950 \u00c5. Unfortunately, this is in a spectral region with strong night sky emission lines. The spectrum obtained from <span class=\"monospace\"><span class=\"small-caps\">modsidl</span></span> processing appears to have significant positive flux in this region (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>), but the sky subtraction in this region did not seem to be reliable. We reprocessed the 2D spectra in this region using a custom 2D spline fit to the background sky emission. The sky subtraction residuals improved considerably after this reprocessing and the residual flux decreased; however, a small positive flux remains. Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig9\" data-open=\"fig9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">9</a> displays the reprocessed spectrum. Although the positive flux residual lies almost exactly at the wavelengths expected for the C\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span> doublet, these wavelengths also align closely with two particularly strong night sky lines and it is difficult to assign a significance to the flux. Taking the noise model for the sky background at face value, we obtain a flux of <em>f</em>(C\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span>) \u2272 6 \u00d7 10<sup>\u221217</sup>erg s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u2009cm<sup>\u22122</sup>. This flux is well below expectation for an AGN, with a flux ratio <em>f</em>(C\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span>)/<em>f</em>(Ly\u00a0\u03b1) \u2272 0.06, compared to \u223c0.2\u20130.5 for narrow-line AGN (Alexandroff et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1\" data-open=\"bib1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Ferland &amp; Osterbrock <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1986</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>ISM absorption features:</em> Given the bright continuum flux of J1414+5446, we are able to obtain constraints of faint interstellar medium (ISM) absorption and emission features. These features provide important diagnostics of the kinematics and covering fraction of neutral gas in the ISM. Stacking analyses provide the best constraints on the strengths of these features in typical <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span> &gt; 3 LBGs (e.g. Jones et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib32\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib32\" data-open=\"bib32\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>); however, a few such galaxies are sufficiently bright for individual study (e.g. Christensen et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Bayliss et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Patr\u00edcio et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib49\" data-open=\"bib49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). In our case, the deep LBT spectrum of a <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span> = 5.4 galaxy achieves only <em>S</em>/<em>N</em> \u223c3pix<sup>\u22121</sup> at \u22731200 \u00c5, and the foreground contamination further reduces the sensitivity to faint spectral features. Nonetheless, we examine several of the ISM features previously studied by Jones et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib32\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib32\" data-open=\"bib32\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) in stacked 3 &lt; <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span> &lt; 7 LBGs, using the wavelengths and velocity offsets listed in their Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>, and adopting Gaussian profiles with widths tuned to match their composite spectrum.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">No ISM features are clearly detected in the LBT spectrum. Si\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> \u03bb1260 has a marginal detection, with <em>W</em> = \u22120.5 \u00b1 0.4(1\u03c3). The Si\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>* \u03bb1264 fine structure line is also marginally detected, with <em>W</em> = 0.3 \u00b1 0.2, as well as Si\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>* \u03bb1309, with <em>W</em> = 0.5 \u00b1 0.3. We obtain limits of <em>W</em> &lt; 0.4 \u00c5 on the O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>+Si\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> \u03bb1303 feature, and <em>W</em> &lt; 0.2 \u00c5 on C\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> \u03bb1334. All other features are too strongly affected by night sky lines to produce meaningful constraints. We have not attempted to correct for the foreground contamination in these measurements; they mainly serve as a guide as to what level of constraint we can obtain given the quality of the available spectrum.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In general, the lack of strong ISM absorption features is consistent with the trend that the equivalent widths of such features anti-correlate with the strength of the Ly\u00a0\u03b1 emission, as detailed in Jones et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib32\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib32\" data-open=\"bib32\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). Thus, we would not have expected to see ISM features in the spectrum of J1414+5446. However, given the strength of the observed continuum flux, an even deeper spectrum obtained with a 30m class telescope would place stronger constraints on the physical conditions of the ISM in this galaxy.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=118502140 id=\"118502140\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-3>4.3 Ionizing spectrum</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We argued in the previous subsection that J1414+5446 lacks the spectroscopic signatures of AGN. However, the N\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span>] detection and questionable C\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span> detection indicate that the nebular gas is subjected to a hard radiation field that is able to ionize these higher order species, with ionization potentials of 47.4\u00a0eV and 47.9\u00a0eV, respectively. Nebular C\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span> detections have been reported in lensed galaxies at <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span> = 7.045 (Stark et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib68\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib68\" data-open=\"bib68\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015b</a>), <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span> = 6.11 (Mainali et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span> = 4.88 (Smit et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib62\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib62\" data-open=\"bib62\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). N\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span>] has been found in a massive galaxy at <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span> = 5.56 (Vanzella et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib70\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib70\" data-open=\"bib70\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) and in lensed galaxies at <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span> = 3.4\u20133.5 (Fosbury et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>; Patr\u00edcio et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib49\" data-open=\"bib49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). While in none of these galaxies \u2013 including the one reported here \u2013 can an AGN contribution be definitively ruled out, photoionization modelling shows that a population of very hot, massive stars could account for the observed nebular emission, in particular, the detections of high-ionization species such as N\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span>]/C\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span> without N\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">v</span> emission as expected from an AGN (e.g. Fosbury et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>). These conditions may be more prevalent during the early stages of galaxy formation, and bright sources like J1414+5446 demonstrate the promise of rest-UV spectroscopy for probing the physical conditions of distant galaxies. It is also noteworthy that N\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span>] is not detected in many galaxies with C\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span> and C\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span> emission (e.g. Stark et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib66\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib66\" data-open=\"bib66\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>), indicating that it may arise only in particular conditions requiring more than just a hard radiation field.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=118502142 id=\"118502142\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-4>4.4 Ly\u00a0\u03b1 velocity offset</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The detection of UV metal lines further provides a measure of the systemic redshift of the galaxy (e.g. Stark et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib67\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib67\" data-open=\"bib67\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015a</a>). The velocity offset of the Ly\u00a0\u03b1 line (\u0394<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$v$|</span><sub>Ly\u00a0\u03b1</sub>) is sensitive to the covering fraction and kinematics of neutral hydrogen; as discussed in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4.2</a>, the Ly\u00a0\u03b1 profile of J1414+5446 is broadly consistent with an expanding, dusty shell of neutral gas. Here, we examine the velocity offset of Ly\u00a0\u03b1 relative to the N\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span>] emission line. The offset between the centroid of the N\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span>] line and the peak of the Ly\u00a0\u03b1 is 70 \u2009km s<sup>\u22121</sup>. Stark et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib67\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib67\" data-open=\"bib67\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015a</a>) measured \u0394<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$v$|</span><sub>Ly\u00a0\u03b1</sub> for two lensed <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span> \u223c6 galaxies with systemic redshifts from C\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>] nebular emission and found smaller offsets than galaxies at 2 &lt; <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span> &lt; 3; however, Willott et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib74\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib74\" data-open=\"bib74\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) detected relatively large (&gt;400\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>) offsets in two luminous <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span> \u223c6 galaxies with systemic redshifts from [C\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>]\u03bb158 \u03bcm and argued that the observed offsets are consistent with the overall trend between \u0394<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$v$|</span><sub>Ly\u00a0\u03b1</sub> and EW<sub>Ly\u00a0\u03b1</sub> seen at lower redshift. The relatively small velocity offset found for J1414+5446 by adopting the N\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span>] redshift is similar to the results of Smit et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib62\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib62\" data-open=\"bib62\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), who found an offset &lt;100 km s<sup>\u22121</sup> for a lensed <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span> = 4.88 galaxy with an extended Ly\u00a0\u03b1 halo (and similarly large Ly\u00a0\u03b1 EW). Larger velocity offsets aid the escape of Ly\u00a0\u03b1 photons through the high-redshift IGM (e.g. Stark et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib69\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib69\" data-open=\"bib69\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>), and thus galaxies with both small velocity offsets and large Ly\u00a0\u03b1 equivalent widths are highly intriguing.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=118502144 id=\"118502144\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-5>4.5 Lensing model</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The lensing group SL2S J141447+544703 was identified by the SL2S (Cabanac et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib11\" data-open=\"bib11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>) based on the detection of a tangential arc (T1) and a candidate bright radial arc (R1). More et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib46\" data-open=\"bib46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) subsequently identified an additional radial arc candidate (R2), bringing the total number of lensed galaxy candidates associated with SL2S J141447+544703 to 3. Images of the three candidate arcs can be viewed in Fig.<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-figa2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"figa2\" data-open=\"figa2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A2</a> in Appendix\u00a0\u00a0<a class=\"js-jumplink\" href=\"#sec6\">A</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Cabanac et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib11\" data-open=\"bib11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>) estimated a photometric redshift of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span> = 0.75 for the galaxy group, while More et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib46\" data-open=\"bib46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) estimated <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span><sub>lens</sub> = 0.63 \u00b1 0.02. We included several candidate group member galaxies in our MODS mask; more complete details are provided in Appendix\u00a0\u00a0<a class=\"js-jumplink\" href=\"#sec6\">A</a>. We obtain a mean redshift of \u27e8<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span><sub>lens</sub>\u27e9 = 0.613 from spectra of 43 galaxies in the group, in excellent agreement with the More et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib46\" data-open=\"bib46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) photometric redshift.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The lensing properties of SL2S J141447+544703 have been discussed in a number of publications. More et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib46\" data-open=\"bib46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) quote an arc radius of 14.7 arcsec for the tangential arc T1. Fo\u00ebx et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>) report a photometric redshift of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z_s=1.47^{+0.75}_{-0.53}$|</span> for the arc and used a shear profile analysis to obtain a velocity dispersion of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\sigma _{\\rm SIS} = 969^{+100}_{-130}\\,{\\rm km}\\,{\\rm s}^{-1}$|</span> for the lens, roughly at the boundary between a group- and cluster-scale lensing mass. Recently, Gruen et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib26\" data-open=\"bib26\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) identified SL2S J141447+544703 with a galaxy cluster detected by the Planck satellite through the Sunyaev-Zel\u2019dovich (SZ) effect (Planck Collaboration et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib52\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib52\" data-open=\"bib52\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014b</a>). Gruen et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib26\" data-open=\"bib26\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) update the results of Fo\u00ebx et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>) and obtain a significantly larger velocity dispersion through weak lensing analysis, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\sigma _{\\rm SIS} = 1540^{+162}_{-190}\\,{\\rm km}\\,{\\rm s}^{-1}$|\u2060</span>. Their measurement of the halo mass is <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M_{500c} \\approx 20\\times 10^{14}h_{70}^{-1} {\\rm M}_{\\odot }$|</span> from weak lensing and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M_{500c} \\approx 8\\times 10^{14}h_{70}^{-1} {\\rm M}_{\\odot }$|</span> from the SZ detection. These larger estimates favour a cluster scale for the foreground mass.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Gruen et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib26\" data-open=\"bib26\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) note that a redshift of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span><sub>s</sub> = 1.49 for the source galaxy of the tangential arc is favoured by their mass model in order to match the observed arc radius, in agreement with the photometric redshift estimate from Fo\u00ebx et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). Spectroscopic redshifts for the candidate arcs are strongly constraining on the lens mass models and hence we observed all three arcs with MODS. For R1 and R2, we obtain redshifts that place them in the foreground of the cluster. For T1, we do not detect any emission lines in the MODS spectra; however, the strongest available line would be [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] \u03bb3727, which at <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span> \u2273 1.5 would be at wavelengths dominated by OH sky lines and thus difficult to detect. Further details of the MODS spectroscopy of targets in the field of J1414+5446 are given in Appendix\u00a0\u00a0<a class=\"js-jumplink\" href=\"#sec6\">A</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We first consider a rough estimate for the lensing magnification of the LAE based on a few simplifying assumptions. J1414+5446 is \u223c30 arcsec from the apparent cluster centre based on the brightest cluster galaxy position and is thus at a radius of \u22482\u03b8<sub>E</sub>, where \u03b8<sub>E</sub> is the Einstein radius. As an example, if we assume an arc redshift of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span> \u2248 2, the lensing magnification from the cluster alone would be \u03bc \u2248 3. However, additional magnification from the foreground galaxy must also be taken into account. Adopting the Faber\u2013Jackson relation given in Bernardi et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib4\" data-open=\"bib4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>) and assuming the foreground galaxy is at the cluster redshift (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$z$|</span> = 0.6) yield a velocity dispersion \u03c3<sub><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$v$|</span></sub> \u2248 85 km s<sup>\u22121</sup> and \u03b8<sub>E</sub> = 0.2 arcsec. Although the Faber\u2013Jackson relation may not be appropriate for this galaxy, this rough estimate demonstrates that the LAE may lie near the Einstein ring radius. Thus, the magnification is difficult to constrain and may be rather large. The <em>HST</em> narrowband imaging provides strong evidence against multiple-image strong lensing of the Ly\u00a0\u03b1-emitting component. The WFPC2 imaging of the far-UV continuum is more ambiguous in that the multiple components are suggestive of a strong lensing configuration. However, we argued in Section <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.2</a> that only a single component in the WFPC2 image is likely associated with the LAE based on the observed colours. Thus, while some ambiguity remains (which could be resolved with further <em>HST</em> or JWST observations), the available <em>HST</em> imaging disfavours multiple-image strong lensing.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In order to better constrain the lensing magnification, we model the cluster mass through an MCMC approach using the <span class=\"small-caps\">lenstool</span> software (Jullo et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib33\" data-open=\"bib33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>), which fits the normalization of the Faber\u2013Jackson scaling relation. The input data are the cluster member galaxies with redshifts from MODS spectroscopy and photometry from <em>HST</em>. The model includes the contribution from the foreground galaxy, which can produce a wide range of amplifications depending on the assumed mass. We thus fold in the photometric uncertainties on the foreground galaxy and make the simplifying assumption that it lies at the cluster redshift.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We execute a series of Monte Carlo simulations that convolve the uncertainties on both the normalization of the scaling relation and the foreground galaxy mass, excluding models that result in multiple image lensing of the LAE (treated as a geometric point source) as the <em>HST</em> imaging suggests that this is unlikely. Finally, we assume a redshift for the lensed arc. The total amplification increases with decreasing arc redshift; in fact, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span> = 1.5 is essentially ruled out as this invariably results in multiple images. In the <em>HST</em> imaging, it is apparent that the lower part of the arc T1 is coincident with an unassociated source of roughly equal brightness. The two objects are blended in the CFHT imaging and this may have affected the previously reported photometric redshifts for the arc (i.e. biasing them to lower redshift). We also note that the large mass estimates from Gruen et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib26\" data-open=\"bib26\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) would produce multiple images of the LAE at other locations in the cluster field, which we do not identify in the <em>HST</em> or CFHT images.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Compared to previous mass modelling of this system, our approach has the advantage of self-consistently including the new member galaxy redshifts we have obtained, the new constraints on the lensed arc candidate redshifts, and most crucially, the presence of the foreground galaxy near the LAE position that strongly perturbs the local magnification map. This results in a highly non-linear estimate for the total lensing magnification of the LAE. Furthermore, the unknown redshift for the lensed arc T1 adds considerable uncertainty to our magnification estimate. We thus investigate the impact of the arc T1 redshift on the LAE magnification by considering three discrete values of redshift in the range 1.5 &lt; <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span> \u2264 2.5<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn5\" data-open=\"fn5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">5</a></sup> in order to explore the uncertainty of the magnification factor.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig10\" data-open=\"fig10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">10</a> presents the distribution of lensing amplifications obtained from these simulations. For <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span> = 2, the median and interquartile ranges are <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mu = 17^{+4}_{-3}$|\u2060</span>. At <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span> = 2.5, this drops to <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mu = 8^{+1.4}_{-1.0}$|\u2060</span>. Given all the uncertainties involved in this analysis, we adopt 5 \u2272 \u03bc \u2272 25 as a conservative estimate for the range of allowed magnifications, thus the intrinsic luminosity of J1414+5446 is poorly constrained. It is likely that the source is intrinsically round and experiencing a relatively low magnification, although scenarios in which the intrinsic source shape conspires with the lensing geometry to produce a high magnification event with little apparent stretching cannot be ruled out. A spectroscopic redshift for the lensed arc T1 would reduce the uncertainty on the magnification but still allow a wide range of values. JWST will have the capability to obtain resolved near-IR spectroscopy of both the foreground interloper and the LAE and thus provide robust constraints on the lensing amplification of this high-redshift galaxy.</p>                        <a id=\"118502154\" scrollto-destination=\"118502154\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig10\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 10.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/1/10.1093_mnras_sty1411/1/m_sty1411fig10.jpeg?Expires=1611465923&amp;Signature=a0xI3QIHRdVriM0TrnXQMFkj~CL8-oMfqBfaNosEIEefeT0YRxuiGVoEQVDYVjCZMDY0SphhDiX-JPOsF40W8Wbgsw23nRa89rVgcXnYHYZxFLPqeWDGZe7NLRXeuzAaWYMPxD1tnQoM-NpVSSaUfrqbckSIgQtgHW78dFwcN7HfXd2YBZicDm5XE0YbIvIOOo6C~ffIUZsFxECT~MR9grR98aOsfW2D0TAHcVOUrxBlqdQFVTBvSm7vqQas-PwUBEinEsBy9BOP~L4PNN1H2W2bjcDvAkhAFSyLzwND0C3hnSHx9BXduQVd7n1fmD4ilNesuuhpWzjiihMGIm~OIA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Lensing amplification factors for J1414+5446 under three assumptions for the redshift of the lensed arc T1. The histograms are the result of Monte Carlo simulations accounting for uncertainties in the foreground interloper photometry and hence its estimated mass, assuming that it lies at the redshift of the cluster. Simulations with \u03bc \u2273 25 tend to result in multiple images and are unlikely, given the observational constraints.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1411fig10.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/118502154/sty1411fig10.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1411fig10.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"118502154\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/1/10.1093_mnras_sty1411/1/sty1411fig10.jpeg?Expires=1611465923&Signature=fCnoJpqSWnuH98GaxIknrwJwK0lsgVu-de7AICZ2aJGXQe1KuCTFS5m4yvJtIHtiHHu6S7hFcwTY0Zsc~B4X7CxPkoHJ-Qkn2cIK-ScmhS2vqXBrvYi7mjnDjbqi6NsWRMF0oj5pmI1GkDRR9Y~u9taXikMds4~aoE~32aFqV-oLxZExeqt7j9bGUqs~MDO9OAqGLjHipu-0b5nLEnFSl~mMEGijYdAtE7FEehfxZysSx1p5HIo0puQi4fQaqQi43xm-SmbesC0NLdHWZFBww55VIgOd0WXkds3KPPDHtq~2uNNft74QEfXYPkpqQIk-rt6gIOKHkEgHPw6GS-Jr3w__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=118502154&ar=5026178&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1411fig10.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Lensing amplification factors for J1414+5446 under three assumptions for the redshift of the lensed arc T1. The histograms are the result of Monte Carlo simulations accounting for uncertainties in the foreground interloper photometry and hence its estimated mass, assuming that it lies at the redshift of the cluster. Simulations with \u03bc \u2273 25 tend to result in multiple images and are unlikely, given the observational constraints.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig10\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 10.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/1/10.1093_mnras_sty1411/1/m_sty1411fig10.jpeg?Expires=1611465923&amp;Signature=a0xI3QIHRdVriM0TrnXQMFkj~CL8-oMfqBfaNosEIEefeT0YRxuiGVoEQVDYVjCZMDY0SphhDiX-JPOsF40W8Wbgsw23nRa89rVgcXnYHYZxFLPqeWDGZe7NLRXeuzAaWYMPxD1tnQoM-NpVSSaUfrqbckSIgQtgHW78dFwcN7HfXd2YBZicDm5XE0YbIvIOOo6C~ffIUZsFxECT~MR9grR98aOsfW2D0TAHcVOUrxBlqdQFVTBvSm7vqQas-PwUBEinEsBy9BOP~L4PNN1H2W2bjcDvAkhAFSyLzwND0C3hnSHx9BXduQVd7n1fmD4ilNesuuhpWzjiihMGIm~OIA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Lensing amplification factors for J1414+5446 under three assumptions for the redshift of the lensed arc T1. The histograms are the result of Monte Carlo simulations accounting for uncertainties in the foreground interloper photometry and hence its estimated mass, assuming that it lies at the redshift of the cluster. Simulations with \u03bc \u2273 25 tend to result in multiple images and are unlikely, given the observational constraints.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1411fig10.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/118502154/sty1411fig10.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1411fig10.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"118502154\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/1/10.1093_mnras_sty1411/1/sty1411fig10.jpeg?Expires=1611465923&Signature=fCnoJpqSWnuH98GaxIknrwJwK0lsgVu-de7AICZ2aJGXQe1KuCTFS5m4yvJtIHtiHHu6S7hFcwTY0Zsc~B4X7CxPkoHJ-Qkn2cIK-ScmhS2vqXBrvYi7mjnDjbqi6NsWRMF0oj5pmI1GkDRR9Y~u9taXikMds4~aoE~32aFqV-oLxZExeqt7j9bGUqs~MDO9OAqGLjHipu-0b5nLEnFSl~mMEGijYdAtE7FEehfxZysSx1p5HIo0puQi4fQaqQi43xm-SmbesC0NLdHWZFBww55VIgOd0WXkds3KPPDHtq~2uNNft74QEfXYPkpqQIk-rt6gIOKHkEgHPw6GS-Jr3w__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=118502154&ar=5026178&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1411fig10.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Lensing amplification factors for J1414+5446 under three assumptions for the redshift of the lensed arc T1. The histograms are the result of Monte Carlo simulations accounting for uncertainties in the foreground interloper photometry and hence its estimated mass, assuming that it lies at the redshift of the cluster. Simulations with \u03bc \u2273 25 tend to result in multiple images and are unlikely, given the observational constraints.</p></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=118502155 id=\"118502155\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-6>4.6 Broadband SED</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We further characterize the properties of J1414+5446 through a detailed analysis of its SED. Before attempting to fit the SED, we must first deblend the foreground contribution from the observed fluxes, particularly in the long wavelength bands where the emission is completely unresolved. We approach this problem by constructing SED templates for the foreground galaxy that reproduce the (semi-)resolved photometry in the bluer bands and use these templates to account for the foreground contribution to the redder bands. This compares to Section <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.2</a>, where we took advantage of the higher resolution provided by <em>HST</em> to obtain deblended photometry of the foreground and LAE at \u03bb &lt; 2 \u03bcm (we consider this photometry to be 'semi'-resolved in that the peaks of the two primary objects are well separated, but the light profiles are significantly blended). Here, we attempt to use simple assumptions about the SED of the foreground galaxy to obtain constraints on the long-wavelength fluxes of the LAE.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The <em>u</em>- and <em>g</em>-band detections are absent and any contribution from the LAE and those fluxes can be assigned to the foreground. The <em>HST</em> data provide photometry from 0.6\u20131.6 \u03bcm, where we adopt the two-component model from Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a> and attribute the fluxes from B+C to the foreground. The resulting photometry is provided in Table <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl5\" data-open=\"tbl5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>. Panel (a) in Fig.<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig11\" data-open=\"fig11\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">11</a> displays the resulting SED for the foreground galaxy, where the points at \u03bb &lt; 2 \u03bcm represent the (semi-)resolved photometry.</p>                        <a id=\"118502158\" scrollto-destination=\"118502158\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig11\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 11.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/1/10.1093_mnras_sty1411/1/m_sty1411fig11.jpeg?Expires=1611465923&amp;Signature=a2bM-oYsi85zvMH1l2KsATxvzXWa0f5UMaEqL-FHgfQgfs4udiJZA53dBYmUhjgpZoc8N8uQKNOvdZ9yrPhb4k7kZchUriOkAxVMhZKAH550a9-xdMgYW4wiqtkP7XjpX6r4E6CBiHgFyoNbsGNxV5P4yjKMnTo74XlMHRdvm31ZYR0FnhnywcrKCaUzbr~LBoInPrT9l4TmiDV0wM4rbMBeCqhZIteCSAoX6KyQKJPkSFF5DUIt1qUu7u5tO4o-SuDXRowpvc1otbmIQV84EMKM4FhoreCD8EQve6sPQlmVIzxSxTWOJWZizX87toE4qS-fGAdXK8h74kyXwngJWw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Photometry and results from SED fitting. The black points with error bars represent the resolved CFHT and HST photometry. The inverted triangles mark the blended photometry from the LBT and Spitzer. Panel (a) shows SED models assumed for the foreground galaxy. Based on the optical photometry, the foreground SED is likely to lie between the Sbc and Scd templates; this provides a range of values used for subtracting the foreground contamination to the infrared data. Panels (b) and (c) present fits to the SED of the $z$ = 5.4 LAE. The grey points with error bars are obtained subtracting the foreground contamination assuming an Sbc SED. The fits are performed to these \u2018decontaminated\u2019 data. Panel (b) displays the fit for a single-stellar population model with a continuous star formation history, while panel (c) presents a composite model consisting of a young (5\u00a0Myr) starbursting component and an evolved (1\u00a0Gyr) population. The blue triangles mark the photometry recovered from the SED fits, offset slightly in wavelength.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1411fig11.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/118502158/sty1411fig11.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1411fig11.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"118502158\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/1/10.1093_mnras_sty1411/1/sty1411fig11.jpeg?Expires=1611465923&Signature=Rv6Tq8iuylLIeS09gkV9oWWD7aB-QRGaHJcGzNnr7nZwW~22wZFFL43bQyzlKREyIlaOgeB5fCG~-KRm9J8GKmhEk2jprHZngOSdM6plhwj8iOYCY7LuDOMyaxhq~MbQ1Uk3ynSZ5zaIsAwD9iUAi-aGDuG~JwF2WCttDMAw7dwsnfy7WE9M2RTi5jApmT2ekh51pnSE1hYVMsfdGoMKWXzgp~kZASj20965Hubg~Bh2vJzjfHfmnobwRQkfN62tjYt4PlphfuDFBk9L3Rykqi1J7HSN-XPDzWdcs6plyjeCtW0uQqcUUGi1WMFvNQZXqDnXhOyzeNol4bCkvxVhkg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=118502158&ar=5026178&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1411fig11.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Photometry and results from SED fitting. The black points with error bars represent the resolved CFHT and <em>HST</em> photometry. The inverted triangles mark the blended photometry from the LBT and Spitzer. Panel (a) shows SED models assumed for the foreground galaxy. Based on the optical photometry, the foreground SED is likely to lie between the Sbc and Scd templates; this provides a range of values used for subtracting the foreground contamination to the infrared data. Panels (b) and (c) present fits to the SED of the <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span> = 5.4 LAE. The grey points with error bars are obtained subtracting the foreground contamination assuming an Sbc SED. The fits are performed to these \u2018decontaminated\u2019 data. Panel (b) displays the fit for a single-stellar population model with a continuous star formation history, while panel (c) presents a composite model consisting of a young (5\u00a0Myr) starbursting component and an evolved (1\u00a0Gyr) population. The blue triangles mark the photometry recovered from the SED fits, offset slightly in wavelength.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig11\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 11.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/1/10.1093_mnras_sty1411/1/m_sty1411fig11.jpeg?Expires=1611465923&amp;Signature=a2bM-oYsi85zvMH1l2KsATxvzXWa0f5UMaEqL-FHgfQgfs4udiJZA53dBYmUhjgpZoc8N8uQKNOvdZ9yrPhb4k7kZchUriOkAxVMhZKAH550a9-xdMgYW4wiqtkP7XjpX6r4E6CBiHgFyoNbsGNxV5P4yjKMnTo74XlMHRdvm31ZYR0FnhnywcrKCaUzbr~LBoInPrT9l4TmiDV0wM4rbMBeCqhZIteCSAoX6KyQKJPkSFF5DUIt1qUu7u5tO4o-SuDXRowpvc1otbmIQV84EMKM4FhoreCD8EQve6sPQlmVIzxSxTWOJWZizX87toE4qS-fGAdXK8h74kyXwngJWw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Photometry and results from SED fitting. The black points with error bars represent the resolved CFHT and HST photometry. The inverted triangles mark the blended photometry from the LBT and Spitzer. Panel (a) shows SED models assumed for the foreground galaxy. Based on the optical photometry, the foreground SED is likely to lie between the Sbc and Scd templates; this provides a range of values used for subtracting the foreground contamination to the infrared data. Panels (b) and (c) present fits to the SED of the $z$ = 5.4 LAE. The grey points with error bars are obtained subtracting the foreground contamination assuming an Sbc SED. The fits are performed to these \u2018decontaminated\u2019 data. Panel (b) displays the fit for a single-stellar population model with a continuous star formation history, while panel (c) presents a composite model consisting of a young (5\u00a0Myr) starbursting component and an evolved (1\u00a0Gyr) population. The blue triangles mark the photometry recovered from the SED fits, offset slightly in wavelength.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1411fig11.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/118502158/sty1411fig11.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1411fig11.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"118502158\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/479/1/10.1093_mnras_sty1411/1/sty1411fig11.jpeg?Expires=1611465923&Signature=Rv6Tq8iuylLIeS09gkV9oWWD7aB-QRGaHJcGzNnr7nZwW~22wZFFL43bQyzlKREyIlaOgeB5fCG~-KRm9J8GKmhEk2jprHZngOSdM6plhwj8iOYCY7LuDOMyaxhq~MbQ1Uk3ynSZ5zaIsAwD9iUAi-aGDuG~JwF2WCttDMAw7dwsnfy7WE9M2RTi5jApmT2ekh51pnSE1hYVMsfdGoMKWXzgp~kZASj20965Hubg~Bh2vJzjfHfmnobwRQkfN62tjYt4PlphfuDFBk9L3Rykqi1J7HSN-XPDzWdcs6plyjeCtW0uQqcUUGi1WMFvNQZXqDnXhOyzeNol4bCkvxVhkg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=118502158&ar=5026178&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty1411fig11.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Photometry and results from SED fitting. The black points with error bars represent the resolved CFHT and <em>HST</em> photometry. The inverted triangles mark the blended photometry from the LBT and Spitzer. Panel (a) shows SED models assumed for the foreground galaxy. Based on the optical photometry, the foreground SED is likely to lie between the Sbc and Scd templates; this provides a range of values used for subtracting the foreground contamination to the infrared data. Panels (b) and (c) present fits to the SED of the <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span> = 5.4 LAE. The grey points with error bars are obtained subtracting the foreground contamination assuming an Sbc SED. The fits are performed to these \u2018decontaminated\u2019 data. Panel (b) displays the fit for a single-stellar population model with a continuous star formation history, while panel (c) presents a composite model consisting of a young (5\u00a0Myr) starbursting component and an evolved (1\u00a0Gyr) population. The blue triangles mark the photometry recovered from the SED fits, offset slightly in wavelength.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">In order to infer the contribution of the foreground to the total fluxes at \u03bb &gt; 2 \u03bcm, we employ the template SEDs from Coleman, Wu &amp; Weedman (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib15\" data-open=\"bib15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1980</a>). These empirical templates are adopted as they provide a small number of simple galaxy archetypes that we utilize to roughly span the range of possible SEDs for the foreground galaxy. We make the simplifying assumption that the foreground galaxy lies at the redshift of the SL2S J141447+544703 group.<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn6\" data-open=\"fn6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">6</a></sup> After fitting to the \u03bb &lt; 2-\u03bcm data, we find that an Sbc template represents the \u2018maximal\u2019 contribution from the foreground galaxy that provides a reasonable fit to the resolved <em>HST</em> photometry. A bluer Scd template is a better match to the <em>u</em> \u2212 <em>g</em> colour from the CFHT photometry but a poorer match to the <em>HST</em> data. Panel (a) of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig11\" data-open=\"fig11\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">11</a> compares these templates to the observed SED of the foreground galaxy. The contributions to the total fluxes (Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>) in the longer wavelength bands for the Sbc (Scd) template are \u223c90 per cent (40 per cent), 40 per cent (20 per cent), and 20 per cent (10 per cent) for the <em>K</em><sub>s</sub>-, 3.6-\u03bcm, and 4.5-\u03bcm bands, respectively.<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn7\" data-open=\"fn7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">7</a></sup></p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Having characterized the SED of the foreground galaxy, we construct the SED for the <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span> = 5.4 LAE from the <em>HST</em> photometry, the LUCI <em>K</em><sub>s</sub>-band image, and the Spitzer/IRAC data. In total, we have six data points spanning 1400\u20137000 \u00c5 in the rest frame of J1414+5446. We construct two versions of the SED, alternately using the Sbc or Scd template fits to subtract the foreground contamination to the <em>K</em><sub>s</sub>/3.6/4.5 bands. We further inflate the photometric errors in these bands by 0.3 mag in order to account for the uncertainty associated with the foreground removal. The Sbc foreground template is more conservative in the sense that it results in smaller fluxes for the LAE in the IRAC bands; the SED obtained after subtracting the Sbc foreground template is displayed in panels (b) and (c) of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig11\" data-open=\"fig11\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">11</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The deblended SED for the LAE is then fit with the method described in Stark et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib65\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib65\" data-open=\"bib65\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>), which includes models for nebular emission presented in Robertson et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib54\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib54\" data-open=\"bib54\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>). Briefly, the stellar population is represented with templates from the (Bruzual &amp; Charlot <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib10\" data-open=\"bib10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>) models, and the nebular emission is self-consistently included by using the ionizing photon output from the stellar population. Accounting for the nebular emission in this galaxy is important as H\u00a0\u03b1 lies in the 4.6-\u03bcm band and [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>] lies in the 3.6-\u03bcm band (H\u00a0\u03b2 is just outside of this band). In all fits, we exclude the <em>K</em><sub>s</sub> band, as it has the largest degree of uncertainty in terms of the foreground contribution. The best-fitting stellar template is found using a grid search of the stellar population parameters and identifying the template with the minimum \u03c7<sup>2</sup> calculated from the observed photometry. Dust extinction is included using the Calzetti, Kinney &amp; Storchi-Bergmann (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib12\" data-open=\"bib12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1994</a>) relation.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The result of the single population fit is shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig11\" data-open=\"fig11\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">11(a)</a>. We find that a single-stellar population model provides a poor fit to the observed SED. The best-fitting model has an age of 1\u00a0Gyr, a star formation rate (SFR) of \u223c50 M<sub>\u2299</sub>\u2009yr<sup>\u22121</sup> (assuming a constant star formation history), and a stellar mass of 3.5 \u00d7 10<sup>10</sup> M<sub>\u2299</sub>, and no dust. The statistical errors on these quantities are at the \u223c10\u201330 per cent level; however, the uncertainties are dominated by systematics in the foreground removal and lens magnification estimate. The results are similar whether the Sbc or Scd template is adopted for the foreground.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We next consider a two-component model. This additional flexibility allows for a young population to account for the blue UV SED, while an older population \u2013 implying significant past star formation \u2013 accounts for the bright IRAC fluxes. Given the small number of photometric data points and the systematic uncertainties mentioned above, the results from these fits must be approached with caution. Nonetheless, we find that the best-fitting model includes a young (starburst) component with a fixed age of 5\u00a0Myr, an (constant) SFR of \u223c100 M<sub>\u2299</sub>\u2009yr<sup>\u22121</sup>, and a stellar mass of \u223c6 \u00d7 10<sup>8</sup>M<sub>\u2299</sub>. The evolved component has an age of 1\u00a0Gyr, SFR \u223c400 M<sub>\u2299</sub>\u2009yr<sup>\u22121</sup>, and stellar mass \u223c3 \u00d7 10<sup>11</sup>M<sub>\u2299</sub>, again assuming a constant star formation history. The evolved population also has <em>E</em>(<em>B</em> \u2212 <em>V</em>) = 0.44. These values change by only \u223c10 per cent whether the Sbc or Scd foreground model is used. As can be seen in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig11\" data-open=\"fig11\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">11(b)</a>, the composite model performs much better at reproducing both the blue UV slope and the bright IRAC fluxes. For the Sbc template, the single population model has a total \u03c7<sup>2</sup> = 8.2 for five data points, while the composite model has \u03c7<sup>2</sup> = 2.9. In both cases, the number of model parameters is large compared to the number of data points and thus the \u03c7<sup>2</sup> statistic should be approached with caution, but this does indicate a significant improvement with the composite model.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In performing these SED fits on the observed fluxes, we are ignoring any magnification due to gravitational lensing. As an example, an arc redshift of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span> = 2.5 would reduce the inferred stellar masses and ages by a factor of \u223c8, suggesting that J1414+5446 is a moderately massive galaxy with a substantial population of older stars. However, an arc redshift of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span> \u2272 2 would suggest that the true stellar mass is lower by more than an order of magnitude. In our fits, we have constrained the stellar age to be less than the age of the universe at <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span> = 5.4, but the observed fluxes push the ages close to this limit. This tension is significantly reduced after correcting for a factor &gt;5 lens magnification that would significantly decrease the inferred age. Regardless of the total stellar mass, the strong emission lines and blue UV slope point toward an ongoing starburst. J1414+5446 will be a prime target for JWST, which can provide resolved photometry and spectroscopy at rest frame optical wavelengths \u2013 including the Balmer series emission lines \u2013 and greatly improved constraints on the current and past star formation in this unusual galaxy.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=118502165 id=\"118502165\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-7>4.7 Star formation</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">There are multiple indicators available to estimate the SFR in J1414+5446. The UV continuum traces the (relatively) unobscured star formation. Adopting the continuum fit from the <em>HST</em> imaging (<em>M</em><sub>1350</sub> = \u221223.0, \u03b2<sub>\u03bb</sub> = \u22122.6) and applying the relation from Madau, Pozzetti &amp; Dickinson (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1998</a>) for a Salpeter IMF and ignoring dust extinction, we obtain a value of \u224880 M<sub>\u2299</sub>\u2009yr<sup>\u22121</sup>. This is consistent with results for the younger stellar population in the two-component SED fits presented in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-6\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-6\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4.6</a>, which are \u223c100 M<sub>\u2299</sub>\u2009yr<sup>\u22121</sup>. On the other hand, the evolved population from the SED fits has a substantial component of dust-obscured star formation, with SFR \u2248 400 M<sub>\u2299</sub>\u2009yr<sup>\u22121</sup> and <em>E</em>(<em>B</em> \u2212 <em>V</em>) \u2248 0.4. The luminosity of the Ly\u00a0\u03b1 line is also consistent with a large SFR. Ignoring dust extinction and applying the Kennicutt (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib35\" data-open=\"bib35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1998</a>) calibration for H\u00a0\u03b1 (assuming Case B recombination and ignoring lensing) to the line luminosity obtained from spectral fitting yields SFR(Ly\u00a0\u03b1) \u2273 400 M<sub>\u2299</sub>\u2009yr<sup>\u22121</sup>. The line luminosities from both the narrowband imaging and the model fitting are \u223c20 per cent larger; note the latter implicitly includes a dust correction. From both the SED and Ly\u00a0\u03b1 profile fitting, we conclude that a substantial amount of obscuring dust may be present, implying a much larger Ly\u00a0\u03b1 SFR after dust correction, which we do not perform here. The gravitational lensing correction acts in the opposite direction and would bring the estimates down by anywhere from a factor of 5\u201325. We conclude that the intrinsic SFR is roughly consistent with being in the range of \u223c10\u2013100 M<sub>\u2299</sub>\u2009yr<sup>\u22121</sup>.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=118502167 id=\"118502167\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5>5 CONCLUSIONS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We present extensive observations of an unusual high-redshift-lensed galaxy. CFHTLS J141446.82+544631.9 was initially targeted as a quasar candidate within the CFHTLS but proved to be an exceptionally bright galaxy at <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span> = 5.426. Our observations lead to the following picture of this interesting object: <ul class=\"roman-lower\"><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">The galaxy is unusually bright for a (likely) non-AGN at <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span> = 5.4 and has one of the largest Ly\u00a0\u03b1 fluxes reported to date. The UV continuum is easily detected and has SNR\u223c3 in a moderate-resolution LBT/MODS1 optical spectrum.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">The strong Ly\u00a0\u03b1 emission from this galaxy suggests a powerful starburst and sightlines through which Ly\u00a0\u03b1 photons can escape. The broad red wing of the line extends over \u223c2000 km s<sup>\u22121</sup> as expected from an outflowing shell. The peak of the Ly\u00a0\u03b1 emission is redshifted by \u223c70 km s<sup>\u22121</sup>.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">Typical AGN emission lines such as N\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">v</span> and C\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span> are not detected. However, the N\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span>] line is detected. Only a few examples of strong N\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span>] emitters exist in the literature; this may be associated with a large population of massive stars keeping the nebular gas in a hot, highly ionized state.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">Fits to the observed SED prefer a two-component model, with a young population to fit the blue UV slope found with resolved <em>HST</em> photometry, and a massive, evolved population indicated by bright IRAC fluxes.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">J1414+5446 lies behind a massive lensing group and has a spatially proximate, faint galaxy in the foreground. This leads to a highly uncertain estimate for the total magnification from gravitational lensing, with values in the range 5 \u2272 \u03bc \u2272 25.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">The unobscured SFR inferred from the Ly\u00a0\u03b1 flux, UV continuum, and UV/optical SED of this galaxy all suggest that it is forming stars at a moderate to prodigious rate (10\u2013100 M<sub>\u2299</sub>\u2009yr<sup>\u22121</sup>). However, these estimates are highly uncertain, given the poorly constrained lensing magnification.</p></li></ul></p><p class=\"chapter-para\">J1414+5446 was found serendipitously, but similar galaxies will be readily discovered in upcoming wide-area surveys such as the HSC-Wide, LSST, and WFIRST. These bright galaxies are prime targets for detailed spectroscopic studies with JWST and 30m-class telescopes, from which a more complete picture of the physical conditions of star-forming galaxies near and within the epoch of re-ionization can be formed. Furthermore, some of the more interesting properties of J1414+5446 provide a guide for future studies of re-ionization-era galaxies. First, the exceptional strength of the Ly\u00a0\u03b1 emission combined with the detection of a high-ionization metal line is suggestive of a population of galaxies with observable Ly\u00a0\u03b1 emission in the re-ionization epoch due to a hard radiation field that ionizes their local bubble (e.g. Stark et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib69\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib69\" data-open=\"bib69\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). Second, the detection of nebular emission lines, in this case N\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span>, provides an alternative path to obtaining redshifts of galaxies even when the Ly\u00a0\u03b1 emission is fully attenuated by a neutral IGM.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=118502170 id=\"118502170\" class=\"backfootnotegroup-title\" >Footnotes</h2>\r\n<div content-id=\"fn1\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn1\" class=\"end-note-link\">1</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\"><a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://www.astronomy.ohio-state.edu/MODS/Software/modsIDL/\" target=\"_blank\">http://www.astronomy.ohio-state.edu/MODS/Software/modsIDL/</a></p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn2\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn2\" class=\"end-note-link\">2</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\"><a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://drizzlepac.stsci.edu/\" target=\"_blank\">http://drizzlepac.stsci.edu/</a></p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn3\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn3\" class=\"end-note-link\">3</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">The simulations are described in greater detail in McGreer et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>) and are based on the forest model of Worseck &amp; Prochaska (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib76\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib76\" data-open=\"bib76\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>), extended to include the incidence of high-redshift Lyman Limit Systems from Songaila &amp; Cowie (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib63\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib63\" data-open=\"bib63\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>).</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn4\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn4\" class=\"end-note-link\">4</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">The lensing correction is highly uncertain and will be discussed in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-5\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4.5</a>.</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn5\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn5\" class=\"end-note-link\">5</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">The arc is unlikely to lie at <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span> &gt; 2.5, given that it is detected in the <em>u</em>-band.</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn6\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn6\" class=\"end-note-link\">6</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">The foreground galaxy is likely to be at low redshift, given the marginal <em>u</em>-band detection.</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn7\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn7\" class=\"end-note-link\">7</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">We also examined photometry of field galaxies covered by the same imaging bands and found that those with SED shapes most similar to the foreground galaxy fell between the Sbc and Scd templates, bolstering the case for using these to bracket the possible foreground contamination.</p></div></span></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=118502178 id=\"118502178\" class=\"backacknowledgements-title\" >ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We thank the anonymous referee for a careful read of the manuscript and suggestions that improved its clarity. These observations are associated with program GO #13762 with support provided by NASA through a grant from the Space Telescope Science Institute. Also based in part on observations made with the Spitzer Space Telescope, which is operated by the Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology under a contract with NASA. ML acknowledges CNRS and CNES for their support. Observations reported here were obtained at the MMT Observatory, a joint facility of the University of Arizona and the Smithsonian Institution. This paper used data obtained with the MODS spectrographs built with funding from NSF grant AST-9987045 and the NSF Telescope System Instrumentation Program (TSIP), with additional funds from the Ohio Board of Regents and the Ohio State University Office of Research. This paper made use of the modsIDL spectral data reduction pipeline developed in part with funds provided by NSF Grant AST-1108693. Based in part on observations obtained with MegaPrime/MegaCam, a joint project of CFHT and CEA/IRFU, at the Canada-France-Hawaii Telescope (CFHT), which is operated by the National Research Council (NRC) of Canada, the Institut National des Science de l\u2019Univers of the Centre National de la Recherche Scientifique (CNRS) of France, and the University of Hawaii. This work is based in part on data products produced at Terapix available at the Canadian Astronomy Data Centre as part of the Canada\u2013France\u2013Hawaii Telescope Legacy Survey, a collaborative project of NRC and CNRS. Science Foundation.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Facilities:</em> CFHT (Megacam), MMT (Red Channel spectrograph), LBT (MODS1, LUCI1), Spitzer (IRAC), and<em>HST</em> (WFPC2,ACS,WFC3).</p> A. A.</div></span> et al.\u00a0</span>, <div class=\"year\">2015</div>, <div class=\"source \">MNRAS</div>, <div class=\"volume\">452</div>, <div class=\"fpage\">1817</div> <div class=\"pub-id\"><a href=\"https://doi.org/10.1093/mnras/stv1403\" class=\"link link-doi openInAnotherWindow\" target=\"_blank\">10.1093/mnras/stv1403</a></div></p><!--citationLinks: case 2--><div class=\"citation-links\"><p class=\"citation-links-compatibility\"><span class=\"crossref\"><a href=\"https://doi.org/10.1093/mnras/stv1403\" class=\"link link-crossref openInAnotherWindow\" target=\"_blank\">Crossref</a></span></p>\u00a0</div></div></div></div></div><div content-id=\"bib10\" data-legacy-id=\"bib10\"><div class=\"refLink-parent\"><span class=\"refLink\"><a P.</div></span> et al.\u00a0</span>, <div class=\"year\">2014</div>, <div class=\"source \">MNRAS</div>, <div class=\"volume\">445</div>, <div class=\"fpage\">3200</div> <div class=\"pub-id\"><a href=\"https://doi.org/10.1093/mnras/stu1618\" class=\"link link-doi openInAnotherWindow\" target=\"_blank\">10.1093/mnras/stu1618</a></div></p><!--citationLinks: case 2--><div class=\"citation-links\"><p class=\"citation-links-compatibility\"><span class=\"crossref\"><a href=\"https://doi.org/10.1093/mnras/stu1618\" class=\"link link-crossref openInAnotherWindow\" target=\"_blank\">Crossref</a></span></p>\u00a0</div></div></div></div></div><div content-id=\"bib67\" data-legacy-id=\"bib67\"><div class=\"refLink-parent\"><span class=\"refLink\"><a name=\"jumplink-bib67\" href=\"javascript:;\" aria-label=\"jumplink-bib67\"></a></span></div><div class=\"ref false\"><div id=\"ref-auto-bib67\" class=\"ref-content \"><div class=\"mixed-citation citation\"><p class=\"mixed-citation-compatibility\"><span class=\"person-group\"><span class=\"name string-name\"><div class=\"surname\">Stark</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">D. E.</div></span>, <span class=\"name string-name\"><div class=\"surname\">Infante</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">L.</div></span></span>, <div class=\"year\">2014</div>, <div class=\"source \">ApJ</div>, <div class=\"volume\">784</div>, <div class=\"fpage\">35</div> <div class=\"pub-id\"><a href=\"https://doi.org/10.1088/0004-637X/784/1/35\" class=\"link link-doi openInAnotherWindow\"
